An Analysis of Arithmetic Constraints on Integer Intervals

Krzysztof R. Apt
CWI, P.O. Box 94079, 1090 GB Amsterdam, the Netherlands and
University of Amsterdam, the Netherlands
Peter Zoeteweij111 The work of the second author was supported by NWO, The Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research, under project number 612.069.003.
Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics and Computer Science,
Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 5031, 2600 GA Delft, the Netherlands
Abstract

Arithmetic constraints on integer intervals are supported in many constraint programming systems. We study here a number of approaches to implement constraint propagation for these constraints. To describe them we introduce integer interval arithmetic. Each approach is explained using appropriate proof rules that reduce the variable domains. We compare these approaches using a set of benchmarks. For the most promising approach we provide results that characterize the effect of constraint propagation.

1 Introduction

1.1 Motivation

The subject of arithmetic constraints on reals has attracted a great deal of attention in the literature. In contrast, arithmetic constraints on integer intervals have not been studied even though they are supported in a number of constraint programming systems. In fact, constraint propagation for them is present in ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT, SICStus Prolog, GNU Prolog, ILOG Solver and undoubtedly most of the systems that support constraint propagation for linear constraints on integer intervals. Yet, in contrast to the case of linear constraints â€” see notably [14] â€” we did not encounter in the literature any analysis of this form of constraint propagation.

In this paper we study these constraints in a systematic way. It turns out that in contrast to linear constraints on integer intervals there are a number of natural approaches to constraint propagation for these constraints. They differ in the extent to which the constraints are decomposed.

Even though arithmetic constraints on integer intervals need not be decomposed into atomic arithmetic constraints, as is common practice for constraints on reals, we found that it is beneficial to do so: it allows for efficient scheduling of the reduction rules and for reuse of auxiliary variables for common subterms between constraints.

It could be argued that since integer arithmetic is a special case of real arithmetic, specialized constraint propagation methods for integer arithmetic constraints are not needed. Indeed, a constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) involving arithmetic constraints on integer variables can be solved using any known method for constraints on reals, with additional constraints ensuring that the variables assume only integer values. This was suggested inÂ [6] and is implemented, for example, in RealPaver [13]. However, a dedicated study and implementation of the integer case is beneficial for a number of reasons.

  • â€¢

    In some cases the knowledge that we are dealing with integers yields a stronger constraint propagation than the approach through the constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on reals. This can be also beneficial when we are dealing with hybrid problems that involve arithmetic constraints on both integer and real variables.

  • â€¢

    The â€˜indirectâ€™ approach through the reals is based on floating-point numbers, which are of limited precision. This implies that no exact representation exists for integers outside certain bounds. We believe that it should be possible to deal with large integers precisely, and that we should not revert to a floating-point representation when other options exist. Using a library like GNU MP [11] we can use arbitrary length integers (called multiple precision integers in GNU MP), whose size is limited only by the available memory.

  • â€¢

    Since arithmetic constraints on integer intervals are supported in a number of constraint programming systems, it is natural to investigate in a systematic way various approaches to their implementation. The approaches based on the integers are amenable to a clear theoretical analysis. In particular, in Section 9 and Subsection 10.1 we provide the characterization results that clarify the effect of constraint propagation for the approach that emerged in our studies as the fastest.

An example that supports the first argument is the constraint xâ‹…y=zâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§x\cdot y=zitalic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z, where âˆ’3â‰¤xâ‰¤33ğ‘¥3-3\leq x\leq 3- 3 â‰¤ italic_x â‰¤ 3, âˆ’1â‰¤yâ‰¤11ğ‘¦1-1\leq y\leq 1- 1 â‰¤ italic_y â‰¤ 1, and 1â‰¤zâ‰¤21ğ‘§21\leq z\leq 21 â‰¤ italic_z â‰¤ 2. When all variables are integers, there are no solutions having x=3ğ‘¥3x=3italic_x = 3 or x=âˆ’3ğ‘¥3x=-3italic_x = - 3, and the constraint propagation methods that we consider here will actually remove these values from the domain of xğ‘¥xitalic_x. However, if these variables are considered to be reals, these values may not be removed, and solving the integer problem through constraint propagation methods for constraints on reals may lead to a larger search space.

As an indication that integer representation is not entirely a theoretical issue, consider the following benchmark from [6]. Find nğ‘›nitalic_n integers x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 1â‰¤xiâ‰¤n1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘›1\leq x_{i}\leq n1 â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_n, verifying the conditions

âˆ‘i=1nxi=âˆ‘i=1ni,âˆi=1nxi=âˆi=1ni,x1â‰¤x2â‰¤â€¦â‰¤xn.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘–formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}i,\quad\prod_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}i,\quad x_{1}\leq x_{2}\leq\ldots\leq x_{n}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i , âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ â€¦ â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

For n=10ğ‘›10n=10italic_n = 10 the initial maximum value of the left-hand side expression of the second constraint equals 1010superscript101010^{10}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which exceeds 232superscript2322^{32}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 32 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the number of values that can be represented as 32-bit integers. For n=16ğ‘›16n=16italic_n = 16, there is already no signed integer representation of this bound in 64 bits.

To show that arbitrary length integers can be affordable, TableÂ 1 shows timing results for three small C++ programs that solve the above benchmark via a basic branch-and-propagate search process. These programs differ only in the representation of the bounds of the variables, and in the signature of the arithmetic operations applied to these bounds: 64-bit floating point numbers (double), 64-bit integers (long long), and arbitrary length integers (using the mpz data type of the GNU MP library). The programs were compiled using the same optimization flags as the default build of the GNU MP library, and the reported CPU times are user time in seconds, measured by the time command on a 1200 MHz AMD Athlon CPU.

The results for 64-bit integers and nâ‰¥16ğ‘›16n\geq 16italic_n â‰¥ 16 could be computed by initializing the upper bound of the auxiliary variable equated to the product of all problem variables to n!ğ‘›n!italic_n !, which works for n<20ğ‘›20n<20italic_n < 20. These results indicate that on our hardware, the 64-bit integer and floating-point implementations are equally efficient, while for these specific problem instances, the cost of using arbitrary length integers is roughly a factor four. Note that in a full-fledged constraint solver, this overhead would be far less prominent, because compared to these small C++ programs, a large part of the execution time is spent in the framework that coordinates the computation (cf. the results in SubsectionÂ 11.2).

1.2 Plan of the Paper

In the next section we provide the relevant background material on CSPs and arithmetic constraints. The unifying tool in our analysis is integer interval arithmetic that is modeled after the real interval arithmetic (see, e.g., [15]). There are, however, essential differences since we deal with integers instead of reals. For example, the product of two integer intervals does not need to be an integer interval. In Section 3 we introduce integer interval arithmetic and establish the basic results. Then in Section 4 we show that using integer interval arithmetic we can define succinctly the well-known constraint propagation for linear constraints on integer intervals.

The next three sections, 5, 6 and 7, form the main part of the paper. We introduce there three approaches to constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals. They differ in the way the constraints are treated: either they are left intact, or the multiple occurrences of variables are eliminated, or the constraints are decomposed into a set of atomic constraints. In SectionÂ 8 we discuss how these three approaches relate to various methods used to solve arithmetic constraints on reals.

Then in Section 9 we characterize the effect of constraint propagation for the atomic constraints. In Section 10 we discuss in detail our implementation of the alternative approaches, and in SectionÂ 11 we describe the experiments that were performed to compare them. They indicate that decomposition of the constraints, combined with a scheduling of the reduction rules that respects the hierarchical dependencies between the atomic constraints is superior to the other approaches. Finally, in SectionÂ 12 we provide the conclusions.

The preliminary results of this work were reported in [2] and [3].

2 Preliminaries

2.1 Constraint Satisfaction Problems

We now review the standard concepts of a constraint and of a constraint satisfaction problem. Consider a sequence of variables X:=x1,â€¦,xnassignğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›X:=x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_X := italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where nâ‰¥0ğ‘›0n\geq 0italic_n â‰¥ 0, with respective domains D1,â€¦,Dnsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT associated with them. In particular, for a variable xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, dâ¢[xi]ğ‘‘delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–d[x_{i}]italic_d [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] denotes disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

A constraint satisfaction problem, in short CSP, consists of a finite sequence of variables Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X with respective domains ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}caligraphic_D, together with a finite set ğ’ğ’\cal Ccaligraphic_C of constraints, each on a subsequence of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X. We write it as âŸ¨ğ’;x1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xnâˆˆDnâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceğ’subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›\langle{\cal C}\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangleâŸ¨ caligraphic_C ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ©, where X:=x1,â€¦,xnassignğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›X:=x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_X := italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’Ÿ:=D1,â€¦,Dnassignğ’Ÿsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›{\cal D}:=D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},D_{n}caligraphic_D := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

By a solution to âŸ¨ğ’;x1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xnâˆˆDnâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceğ’subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›\langle{\cal C}\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangleâŸ¨ caligraphic_C ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© we mean an element dâˆˆD1Ã—â€¦Ã—Dnğ‘‘subscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›d\in D_{1}\times\mbox{$\ldots$}\times D_{n}italic_d âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— â€¦ Ã— italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that for each constraint Câˆˆğ’ğ¶ğ’C\in{\cal C}italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C on a sequence of variables Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X we have dâ¢[X]âˆˆCğ‘‘delimited-[]ğ‘‹ğ¶d[X]\in Citalic_d [ italic_X ] âˆˆ italic_C. We call a CSP consistent if it has a solution and inconsistent if it does not. Two CSPs with the same sequence of variables are called equivalent if they have the same set of solutions. In what follows we consider CSPs whose constraints are defined in a simple language and when reasoning about them we identify the syntactic description of a constraint with its meaning being the set of tuples that satisfy it.

We view constraint propagation as a process of transforming CSPs that maintains their equivalence. In what follows we define this process by means of proof rules that operate on CSPs and preserve equivalence. An interested reader can consult [1] or [2] for a precise explanation of this approach to describing constraint propagation.

2.2 Arithmetic Constraints

To define the arithmetic constraints we use the alphabet that comprises

  • â€¢

    variables,

  • â€¢

    two constants, 0 and 1,

  • â€¢

    the unary minus function symbol â€˜âˆ’--â€™,

  • â€¢

    three binary function symbols, â€˜+â€™,â€˜âˆ’--â€™and â€˜â‹…â‹…\cdotâ‹…â€™, all written in the infix notation.

By an arithmetic expression we mean a term formed in this alphabet and by an arithmetic constraint a formula of the form

sâ¢oâ¢pâ¢t,ğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘¡s\>op\>t,italic_s italic_o italic_p italic_t ,

where sğ‘ sitalic_s and tğ‘¡titalic_t are arithmetic expressions and oâ¢pâˆˆ{<,â‰¤,=,â‰ ,â‰¥,>}ğ‘œğ‘op\in\mbox{$\{{<,\leq,=,\neq,\geq,>}\}$}italic_o italic_p âˆˆ { < , â‰¤ , = , â‰  , â‰¥ , > }. For example

x5â‹…y2â‹…z4+3â¢xâ‹…y3â‹…z5â‰¤10+4â¢x4â‹…y6â‹…z2âˆ’y2â‹…x5â‹…z4â‹…superscriptğ‘¥5superscriptğ‘¦2superscriptğ‘§4â‹…3ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦3superscriptğ‘§510â‹…4superscriptğ‘¥4superscriptğ‘¦6superscriptğ‘§2â‹…superscriptğ‘¦2superscriptğ‘¥5superscriptğ‘§4x^{5}\cdot y^{2}\cdot z^{4}+3x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}\leq 10+4x^{4}\cdot y^{6}\cdot z^{2}-y^{2}\cdot x^{5}\cdot z^{4}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 10 + 4 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (1)

is an arithmetic constraint. Here x5superscriptğ‘¥5x^{5}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an abbreviation for xâ‹…xâ‹…xâ‹…xâ‹…xâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥x\cdot x\cdot x\cdot x\cdot xitalic_x â‹… italic_x â‹… italic_x â‹… italic_x â‹… italic_x, while 3â¢xâ‹…y3â‹…z5â‹…3ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦3superscriptğ‘§53x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}3 italic_x â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an abbreviation for xâ‹…y3â‹…z5+xâ‹…y3â‹…z5+xâ‹…y3â‹…z5â‹…ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦3superscriptğ‘§5â‹…ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦3superscriptğ‘§5â‹…ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦3superscriptğ‘§5x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}+x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}+x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}italic_x â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and similarly with the other expressions. If â€˜â‹…â‹…\cdotâ‹…â€™ is not used in an arithmetic constraint, we call it a linear constraint.

By an extended arithmetic expression we mean a term formed in the above alphabet extended by the unary function symbols â€˜â‹…nsuperscriptâ‹…ğ‘›\cdot^{n}â‹… start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€™ and â€˜â‹…nğ‘›â‹…\sqrt[n]{\cdot}nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG â‹… end_ARGâ€™ for each nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1italic_n â‰¥ 1 and the binary function symbol â€˜///â€™ written in the infix notation. For example

(y2â‹…z4)/(x2â‹…u5)33â‹…superscriptğ‘¦2superscriptğ‘§4â‹…superscriptğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘¢5\sqrt[3]{(y^{2}\cdot z^{4})/(x^{2}\cdot u^{5})}nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) / ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG (2)

is an extended arithmetic expression. Here, unlike in (1), x5superscriptğ‘¥5x^{5}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a term obtained by applying the function symbol â€˜â‹…5superscriptâ‹…5\cdot^{5}â‹… start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€™ to the variable xğ‘¥xitalic_x. The extended arithmetic expressions will be used only to define constraint propagation for the arithmetic constraints.

Fix now some arbitrary linear ordering â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º on the variables of the language. By a monomial we mean an integer or a term of the form

aâ‹…x1n1â‹…â€¦â‹…xknkâ‹…ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘›1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜a\cdot x_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot x_{k}^{n_{k}}italic_a â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… â€¦ â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

where k>0ğ‘˜0k>0italic_k > 0, x1,â€¦,xksubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different variables ordered w.r.t.Â â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º, and ağ‘aitalic_a is a non-zero integer and n1,â€¦,nksubscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},n_{k}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positive integers. We call then x1n1â‹…â€¦â‹…xknkâ‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘›1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜x_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot x_{k}^{n_{k}}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… â€¦ â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the power product of this monomial.

Next, by a polynomial we mean a term of the form

Î£i=1nâ¢mi,subscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘›ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}m_{i},roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where n>0ğ‘›0n>0italic_n > 0, at most one monomial misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an integer, and the power products of the monomials m1,â€¦,mnsubscriptğ‘š1â€¦subscriptğ‘šğ‘›m_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},m_{n}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are pairwise different. Finally, by a polynomial constraint we mean an arithmetic constraint of the form sâ¢oâ¢pâ¢bğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘s\>op\>bitalic_s italic_o italic_p italic_b, where sğ‘ sitalic_s is a polynomial with no monomial being an integer, oâ¢pâˆˆ{<,â‰¤,=,â‰ ,â‰¥,>}ğ‘œğ‘op\in\mbox{$\{{<,\leq,=,\neq,\geq,>}\}$}italic_o italic_p âˆˆ { < , â‰¤ , = , â‰  , â‰¥ , > }, and bğ‘bitalic_b is an integer. It is clear that by means of appropriate transformation rules we can transform each arithmetic constraint to a polynomial constraint. For example, assuming the ordering xâ‰ºyâ‰ºzprecedesğ‘¥ğ‘¦precedesğ‘§x\prec y\prec zitalic_x â‰º italic_y â‰º italic_z on the variables, the arithmetic constraint (1) can be transformed to the polynomial constraint

2â¢x5â‹…y2â‹…z4âˆ’4â¢x4â‹…y6â‹…z2+3â¢xâ‹…y3â‹…z5â‰¤10â‹…2superscriptğ‘¥5superscriptğ‘¦2superscriptğ‘§4â‹…4superscriptğ‘¥4superscriptğ‘¦6superscriptğ‘§2â‹…3ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦3superscriptğ‘§5102x^{5}\cdot y^{2}\cdot z^{4}-4x^{4}\cdot y^{6}\cdot z^{2}+3x\cdot y^{3}\cdot z^{5}\leq 102 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 10

So, without loss of generality, from now on we shall limit our attention to polynomial constraints.

Next, let us discuss the domains over which we interpret the arithmetic constraints. By an integer interval, or an interval in short, we mean an expression of the form

[a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ]

where ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b are integers; [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ] denotes the set of all integers between ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b, including ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b. If a>bğ‘ğ‘a>bitalic_a > italic_b, we call [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ] the empty interval and denote it by âˆ…\emptysetâˆ…. By a range we mean an expression of the form

xâˆˆIğ‘¥ğ¼x\in Iitalic_x âˆˆ italic_I

where xğ‘¥xitalic_x is a variable and Iğ¼Iitalic_I is an interval. Sets of the form {xâˆˆğ’µ|xâ‰¥a}conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’µğ‘¥ğ‘\{x\in\mathcal{Z}|x\geq a\}{ italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_Z | italic_x â‰¥ italic_a } and {xâˆˆğ’µ|xâ‰¤b}conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’µğ‘¥ğ‘\{x\in\mathcal{Z}|x\leq b\}{ italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_Z | italic_x â‰¤ italic_b } are called extended intervals.

We link the arithmetic constraints with the notion of a constraint defined in the previous section by associating in the standard way with each arithmetic constraint its interpretation. For an arithmetic constraint on variables x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respective integer interval domains D1,â€¦,Dnsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT this is a subset of D1Ã—â€¦Ã—Dnsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{1}\times\mbox{$\ldots$}\times D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— â€¦ Ã— italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3 Integer Set Arithmetic

To reason about the arithmetic constraints we employ a generalization of the arithmetic operations to the sets of integers. Here and elsewhere ğ’µğ’µ{\cal Z}caligraphic_Z, ğ’©ğ’©{\cal N}caligraphic_N, and â„›â„›{\cal R}caligraphic_R denote the sets of all integers, natural numbers, and reals, respectively.

3.1 Definitions

For X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y sets of integers we define the following operations:

  • â€¢

    addition:

    X+Y:={x+yâˆ£xâˆˆX,yâˆˆY},assignğ‘‹ğ‘Œconditional-setğ‘¥ğ‘¦formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ‘¦ğ‘ŒX+Y:=\mbox{$\{{x+y\mid x\in X,y\in Y}\}$},italic_X + italic_Y := { italic_x + italic_y âˆ£ italic_x âˆˆ italic_X , italic_y âˆˆ italic_Y } ,
  • â€¢

    subtraction:

    Xâˆ’Y:={xâˆ’yâˆ£xâˆˆX,yâˆˆY},assignğ‘‹ğ‘Œconditional-setğ‘¥ğ‘¦formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ‘¦ğ‘ŒX-Y:=\mbox{$\{{x-y\mid x\in X,y\in Y}\}$},italic_X - italic_Y := { italic_x - italic_y âˆ£ italic_x âˆˆ italic_X , italic_y âˆˆ italic_Y } ,
  • â€¢

    multiplication:

    Xâ‹…Y:={xâ‹…yâˆ£xâˆˆX,yâˆˆY},assignâ‹…ğ‘‹ğ‘Œconditional-setâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ‘¦ğ‘ŒX\cdot Y:=\mbox{$\{{x\cdot y\mid x\in X,y\in Y}\}$},italic_X â‹… italic_Y := { italic_x â‹… italic_y âˆ£ italic_x âˆˆ italic_X , italic_y âˆˆ italic_Y } ,
  • â€¢

    division:

    X/Y:={uâˆˆğ’µâˆ£âˆƒxâˆˆXâ¢âˆƒyâˆˆYâ¢uâ‹…y=x},assignğ‘‹ğ‘Œconditional-setğ‘¢ğ’µğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ‘¦â‹…ğ‘Œğ‘¢ğ‘¦ğ‘¥X/Y:=\mbox{$\{{u\in{\cal Z}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}x\in X\mbox{$\exists$}y\in Y\>u\cdot y=x}\}$},italic_X / italic_Y := { italic_u âˆˆ caligraphic_Z âˆ£ âˆƒ italic_x âˆˆ italic_X âˆƒ italic_y âˆˆ italic_Y italic_u â‹… italic_y = italic_x } ,
  • â€¢

    exponentiation:

    Xn:={xnâˆ£xâˆˆX},assignsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›conditional-setsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘¥ğ‘‹X^{n}:=\mbox{$\{{x^{n}\mid x\in X}\}$},italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := { italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_x âˆˆ italic_X } ,

    for each natural number n>0ğ‘›0n>0italic_n > 0,

  • â€¢

    root extraction:

    Xn:={xâˆˆğ’µâˆ£xnâˆˆX},assignğ‘›ğ‘‹conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’µsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘‹\sqrt[n]{X}:=\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid x^{n}\in X}\}$},nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_X end_ARG := { italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_Z âˆ£ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_X } ,

    for each natural number n>0ğ‘›0n>0italic_n > 0.

All the operations except division and root extraction are defined in the expected way. We shall return to the division operation in SectionÂ 7. At the moment it suffices to note the division operation is defined for all sets of integers, including Y=âˆ…ğ‘ŒY=\mbox{$\emptyset$}italic_Y = âˆ… and Y={0}ğ‘Œ0Y=\mbox{$\{{0}\}$}italic_Y = { 0 }. This division operation corresponds to the following division operation on the sets of reals introduced in [18]:

XâŠ˜Y:={uâˆˆâ„›âˆ£âˆƒxâˆˆXâ¢âˆƒyâˆˆYâ¢uâ‹…y=x}.assignâŠ˜ğ‘‹ğ‘Œconditional-setğ‘¢â„›ğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ‘¦â‹…ğ‘Œğ‘¢ğ‘¦ğ‘¥X\oslash Y:=\mbox{$\{{u\in{\cal R}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}x\in X\mbox{$\exists$}y\in Y\>u\cdot y=x}\}$}.italic_X âŠ˜ italic_Y := { italic_u âˆˆ caligraphic_R âˆ£ âˆƒ italic_x âˆˆ italic_X âˆƒ italic_y âˆˆ italic_Y italic_u â‹… italic_y = italic_x } .

For an integer or real number ağ‘aitalic_a and oâ¢pâˆˆ{+,âˆ’,â‹…,/,âŠ˜}ğ‘œğ‘â‹…âŠ˜op\in\mbox{$\{{+,-,\cdot,/,\oslash}\}$}italic_o italic_p âˆˆ { + , - , â‹… , / , âŠ˜ } we identify aâ¢oâ¢pâ¢Xğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘‹a\>op\>Xitalic_a italic_o italic_p italic_X with {a}â¢oâ¢pâ¢Xğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘‹\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}\>op\>X{ italic_a } italic_o italic_p italic_X and Xâ¢oâ¢pâ¢ağ‘‹ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘X\>op\>aitalic_X italic_o italic_p italic_a with Xâ¢oâ¢pâ¢{a}ğ‘‹ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘X\>op\>\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}italic_X italic_o italic_p { italic_a }.

To present the rules we are interested in we shall also use the addition and division operations on the sets of reals. Addition is defined in the same way as for the sets of integers, and for division we use the âŠ˜âŠ˜\oslashâŠ˜ operator defined above. In [15] it is explained how to implement these operations on, possibly unbounded, real intervals.

Further, given a set Ağ´Aitalic_A of integers or reals, we define

Aâ‰¤:={xâˆˆğ’µâˆ£âˆƒaâˆˆAâ¢xâ‰¤a},assignsuperscriptğ´conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’µğ‘ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘{}^{\leq}A:=\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}a\in A\>x\leq a}\}$},start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_A := { italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_Z âˆ£ âˆƒ italic_a âˆˆ italic_A italic_x â‰¤ italic_a } ,
Aâ‰¥:={xâˆˆğ’µâˆ£âˆƒaâˆˆAâ¢xâ‰¥a},assignsuperscriptğ´conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’µğ‘ğ´ğ‘¥ğ‘{}^{\geq}A:=\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}a\in A\>x\geq a}\}$},start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_A := { italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_Z âˆ£ âˆƒ italic_a âˆˆ italic_A italic_x â‰¥ italic_a } ,

so for example ğ’©â‰¤=ğ’µsuperscriptğ’©ğ’µ{}^{\leq}{\mathcal{N}}=\mathcal{Z}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_N = caligraphic_Z, and {âˆ’1,1}â‰¥{}^{\geq}\{-1,1\}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT { - 1 , 1 } and (âˆ’2,2)â‰¥{}^{\geq}(-2,2)start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ( - 2 , 2 ) both denote the extended interval of all integers greater than or equal to âˆ’11-1- 1, where (âˆ’2,2)22(-2,2)( - 2 , 2 ) denotes an open interval of real numbers.

When limiting our attention to intervals of integers the following simple observation is of importance.

Note 3.1

For X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y integer intervals and ağ‘aitalic_a an integer the following holds:

  • â€¢

    Xâˆ©Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX\cap Yitalic_X âˆ© italic_Y, X+Y,Xâˆ’Yğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX+Y,X-Yitalic_X + italic_Y , italic_X - italic_Y are integer intervals.

  • â€¢

    X/{a}ğ‘‹ğ‘X/\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}italic_X / { italic_a } is an integer interval.

  • â€¢

    Xâ‹…Yâ‹…ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX\cdot Yitalic_X â‹… italic_Y does not have to be an integer interval, even if X={a}ğ‘‹ğ‘X=\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}italic_X = { italic_a } or Y={a}ğ‘Œğ‘Y=\mbox{$\{{a}\}$}italic_Y = { italic_a }.

  • â€¢

    X/Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX/Yitalic_X / italic_Y does not have to be an integer interval.

  • â€¢

    For each n>1ğ‘›1n>1italic_n > 1, Â Xnsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X^{n}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not have to be an integer interval.

  • â€¢

    For odd n>1ğ‘›1n>1italic_n > 1, Â Xnğ‘›ğ‘‹\sqrt[n]{X}nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_X end_ARG is an integer interval.

  • â€¢

    For even n>1ğ‘›1n>1italic_n > 1, Â Xnğ‘›ğ‘‹\sqrt[n]{X}nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_X end_ARG is an integer interval or a disjoint union of two integer intervals. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

For example in the following cases we get intervals as outcomes:

[2..4]+[3..8]=[5..12],delimited-[]2..4delimited-[]3..8delimited-[]5..12[2..4]+[3..8]=[5..12],[ 2..4 ] + [ 3..8 ] = [ 5..12 ] ,
[3..7]âˆ’[1..8]=[âˆ’5..6],delimited-[]3..7delimited-[]1..8delimited-[]5..6[3..7]-[1..8]=[-5..6],[ 3..7 ] - [ 1..8 ] = [ - 5..6 ] ,
[âˆ’30..100]3=[âˆ’3..4],3delimited-[]30..100delimited-[]3..4\sqrt[3]{[-30..100]}=[-3..4],nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG [ - 30..100 ] end_ARG = [ - 3..4 ] ,
[âˆ’100..9]2=[âˆ’3..3],2delimited-[]100..9delimited-[]3..3\sqrt[2]{[-100..9]}=[-3..3],nth-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG [ - 100..9 ] end_ARG = [ - 3..3 ] ,

while in the following ones not:

[3..3]â‹…[1..2]={3,6},â‹…delimited-[]3..3delimited-[]1..236[3..3]\cdot[1..2]=\mbox{$\{{3,6}\}$},[ 3..3 ] â‹… [ 1..2 ] = { 3 , 6 } ,
[3..5]/[âˆ’1..2]={âˆ’5,âˆ’4,âˆ’3,2,3,4,5},delimited-[]3..5delimited-[]1..25432345[3..5]/[-1..2]=\mbox{$\{{-5,-4,-3,2,3,4,5}\}$},[ 3..5 ] / [ - 1..2 ] = { - 5 , - 4 , - 3 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 } ,
[âˆ’3..5]/[âˆ’1..2]=ğ’µ,delimited-[]3..5delimited-[]1..2ğ’µ[-3..5]/[-1..2]={\cal Z},[ - 3..5 ] / [ - 1..2 ] = caligraphic_Z ,
[1..2]2={1,4},superscriptdelimited-[]1..2214[1..2]^{2}=\mbox{$\{{1,4}\}$},[ 1..2 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { 1 , 4 } ,
[1..9]2=[âˆ’3..âˆ’1]âˆª[1..3].\sqrt[2]{[1..9]}=[-3..-1]\cup[1..3].nth-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG [ 1..9 ] end_ARG = [ - 3 . . - 1 ] âˆª [ 1..3 ] .

To deal with the problem that non-interval domains can be produced by some of the operations we introduce the following operation on the sets of integers:

int(X):={smallest integer interval containingÂ XifÂ XÂ is finite,ğ’µotherwise.\operatorname{int}(X):=\left\{\begin{tabular}[]{ll}\mbox{smallest integer interval containing $X$}&\mbox{if $X$ is finite,}\\ ${\cal Z}$&\mbox{otherwise.}\end{tabular}\right.roman_int ( italic_X ) := { start_ROW start_CELL smallest integer interval containing X end_CELL start_CELL if X is finite, end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_Z end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW

For example intâ¡([3..5]/[âˆ’1..2])=[âˆ’5..5]intdelimited-[]3..5delimited-[]1..2delimited-[]5..5\operatorname{int}([3..5]/[-1..2])=[-5..5]roman_int ( [ 3..5 ] / [ - 1..2 ] ) = [ - 5..5 ] and intâ¡([âˆ’3..5]/[âˆ’1..2])=ğ’µintdelimited-[]3..5delimited-[]1..2ğ’µ\operatorname{int}([-3..5]/[-1..2])={\cal Z}roman_int ( [ - 3..5 ] / [ - 1..2 ] ) = caligraphic_Z.

3.2 Implementation

To define constraint propagation for the arithmetic constraints on integer intervals we shall use the integer set arithmetic, mainly limited to the integer intervals. This brings us to the discussion of how to implement the introduced operations on the integer intervals. Since we are only interested in maintaining the property that the sets remain integer intervals or the set of integers ğ’µğ’µ{\cal Z}caligraphic_Z we shall clarify how to implement the intersection, addition, subtraction and root extraction operations of the integer intervals and the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) closure of the multiplication, division and exponentiation operations on the integer intervals. The case when one of the intervals is empty is easy to deal with. So we assume that we deal with non-empty intervals [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ] and [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ], that is aâ‰¤bğ‘ğ‘a\leq bitalic_a â‰¤ italic_b and câ‰¤dğ‘ğ‘‘c\leq ditalic_c â‰¤ italic_d.

Intersection, addition and subtraction

It is easy to see that

[a..b]âˆ©[c..d]=[max(a,c)..min(b,d)],[a..b]\cap[c..d]=[\operatorname{max}(a,c)..\operatorname{min}(b,d)],[ italic_a . . italic_b ] âˆ© [ italic_c . . italic_d ] = [ roman_max ( italic_a , italic_c ) . . roman_min ( italic_b , italic_d ) ] ,
[a..b]+[c..d]=[a+c..b+d],[a..b]+[c..d]=[a+c\ ..\ b+d],[ italic_a . . italic_b ] + [ italic_c . . italic_d ] = [ italic_a + italic_c . . italic_b + italic_d ] ,
[a..b]âˆ’[c..d]=[aâˆ’d..bâˆ’c].[a..b]-[c..d]=[a-d\ ..\ b-c].[ italic_a . . italic_b ] - [ italic_c . . italic_d ] = [ italic_a - italic_d . . italic_b - italic_c ] .

So the interval intersection, addition, and subtraction are straightforward to implement.

Root extraction

The outcome of the root extraction operator applied to an integer interval will be an integer interval or a disjoint union of two integer intervals. We shall explain in Section 5 why it is advantageous not to apply intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) to the outcome. This operator can be implemented by means of the following case analysis.

Case 1. Suppose nğ‘›nitalic_n is odd. Then

[a..b]n=[âŒˆanâŒ‰..âŒŠbnâŒ‹].\sqrt[n]{[a..b]}=[\left\lceil\sqrt[n]{a}\right\rceil..\left\lfloor\sqrt[n]{b}\right\rfloor].nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG [ italic_a . . italic_b ] end_ARG = [ âŒˆ nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_a end_ARG âŒ‰ . . âŒŠ nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_b end_ARG âŒ‹ ] .

Case 2. Suppose nğ‘›nitalic_n is even and b<0ğ‘0b<0italic_b < 0. Then

[a..b]n=âˆ….\sqrt[n]{[a..b]}=\mbox{$\emptyset$}.nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG [ italic_a . . italic_b ] end_ARG = âˆ… .

Case 3. Suppose nğ‘›nitalic_n is even and bâ‰¥0ğ‘0b\geq 0italic_b â‰¥ 0. Then

[a..b]n=[âˆ’âŒŠ|bn|âŒ‹..âˆ’âŒˆ|a+n|âŒ‰]âˆª[âŒˆ|a+n|âŒ‰..âŒŠ|bn|âŒ‹]\sqrt[n]{[a..b]}=[-\left\lfloor|\sqrt[n]{b}|\right\rfloor..-\left\lceil|\sqrt[n]{a_{+}}|\right\rceil]\cup[\left\lceil|\sqrt[n]{a_{+}}|\right\rceil..\left\lfloor|\sqrt[n]{b}|\right\rfloor]nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG [ italic_a . . italic_b ] end_ARG = [ - âŒŠ | nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_b end_ARG | âŒ‹ . . - âŒˆ | nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | âŒ‰ ] âˆª [ âŒˆ | nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | âŒ‰ . . âŒŠ | nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_b end_ARG | âŒ‹ ]

where a+:=maxâ¡(0,a)assignsubscriptğ‘max0ğ‘a_{+}:=\operatorname{max}(0,a)italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_max ( 0 , italic_a ).

Multiplication

For the remaining operations we only need to explain how to implement the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) closure of the outcome. First note that

int([a..b]â‹…[c..d])=[min(A)..max(A)],\operatorname{int}([a..b]\cdot[c..d])=[\operatorname{min}(A)..\operatorname{max}(A)],roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] â‹… [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = [ roman_min ( italic_A ) . . roman_max ( italic_A ) ] ,

where A={aâ‹…c,aâ‹…d,bâ‹…c,bâ‹…d}ğ´â‹…ğ‘ğ‘â‹…ğ‘ğ‘‘â‹…ğ‘ğ‘â‹…ğ‘ğ‘‘A=\mbox{$\{{a\cdot c,a\cdot d,b\cdot c,b\cdot d}\}$}italic_A = { italic_a â‹… italic_c , italic_a â‹… italic_d , italic_b â‹… italic_c , italic_b â‹… italic_d }.

Using an appropriate case analysis we can actually compute the bounds of int([a..b]â‹…[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]\cdot[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] â‹… [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) directly in terms of the bounds of the constituent intervals.

Division

In contrast, the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) closure of the interval division is not so straightforward to compute. The reason is that, as we shall see in a moment, we cannot express the result in terms of some simple operations on the interval bounds.

Consider non-empty integer intervals [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ] and [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ]. In analyzing the outcome of int([a..b]/[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) we distinguish the following cases.

Case 1. Suppose 0âˆˆ[a..b]0\in[a..b]0 âˆˆ [ italic_a . . italic_b ] and 0âˆˆ[c..d]0\in[c..d]0 âˆˆ [ italic_c . . italic_d ].

Then by definition int([a..b]/[c..d])=ğ’µ\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])={\cal Z}roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = caligraphic_Z. For example,

intâ¡([âˆ’1..100]/[âˆ’2..8])=ğ’µ.intdelimited-[]1..100delimited-[]2..8ğ’µ\operatorname{int}([-1..100]/[-2..8])={\cal Z}.roman_int ( [ - 1..100 ] / [ - 2..8 ] ) = caligraphic_Z .

Case 2. Suppose 0âˆ‰[a..b]0\not\in[a..b]0 âˆ‰ [ italic_a . . italic_b ] and c=d=0ğ‘ğ‘‘0c=d=0italic_c = italic_d = 0.

Then by definition int([a..b]/[c..d])=âˆ…\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])=\mbox{$\emptyset$}roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = âˆ…. For example,

intâ¡([10..100]/[0..0])=âˆ….intdelimited-[]10..100delimited-[]0..0\operatorname{int}([10..100]/[0..0])=\mbox{$\emptyset$}.roman_int ( [ 10..100 ] / [ 0..0 ] ) = âˆ… .

Case 3. Suppose 0âˆ‰[a..b]0\not\in[a..b]0 âˆ‰ [ italic_a . . italic_b ] and c<0ğ‘0c<0italic_c < 0 and 0<d0ğ‘‘0<d0 < italic_d.

It is easy to see that then

int([a..b]/[c..d])=[âˆ’e..e],\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])=[-e..e],roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = [ - italic_e . . italic_e ] ,

where e=maxâ¡(|a|,|b|)ğ‘’maxğ‘ğ‘e=\operatorname{max}(|a|,|b|)italic_e = roman_max ( | italic_a | , | italic_b | ). For example,

int([âˆ’100..âˆ’10]/[âˆ’2..5])=[âˆ’100..100].\operatorname{int}([-100..-10]/[-2..5])=[-100..100].roman_int ( [ - 100 . . - 10 ] / [ - 2..5 ] ) = [ - 100..100 ] .

Case 4. Suppose 0âˆ‰[a..b]0\not\in[a..b]0 âˆ‰ [ italic_a . . italic_b ] and either c=0ğ‘0c=0italic_c = 0 and dâ‰ 0ğ‘‘0d\neq 0italic_d â‰  0 or câ‰ 0ğ‘0c\neq 0italic_c â‰  0 and d=0ğ‘‘0d=0italic_d = 0.

Then int([a..b]/[c..d])=int([a..b]/([c..d]âˆ’{0}))\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])=\operatorname{int}([a..b]/([c..d]-\mbox{$\{{0}\}$}))roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / ( [ italic_c . . italic_d ] - { 0 } ) ). For example

int([1..100]/[âˆ’7..0])=int([1..100]/[âˆ’7..âˆ’1]).\operatorname{int}([1..100]/[-7..0])=\operatorname{int}([1..100]/[-7..-1]).roman_int ( [ 1..100 ] / [ - 7..0 ] ) = roman_int ( [ 1..100 ] / [ - 7 . . - 1 ] ) .

This allows us to reduce this case to Case 5 below.

Case 5. Suppose 0âˆ‰[c..d]0\not\in[c..d]0 âˆ‰ [ italic_c . . italic_d ].

This is the only case when we need to compute int([a..b]/[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) indirectly. First, observe that we have

int([a..b]/[c..d])âŠ†[âŒˆmin(A)âŒ‰..âŒŠmax(A)âŒ‹],\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])\mbox{$\>\subseteq\>$}[\left\lceil\operatorname{min}(A)\right\rceil..\left\lfloor\operatorname{max}(A)\right\rfloor],roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) âŠ† [ âŒˆ roman_min ( italic_A ) âŒ‰ . . âŒŠ roman_max ( italic_A ) âŒ‹ ] ,

where A={a/c,a/d,b/c,b/d}ğ´ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘A=\mbox{$\{{a/c,a/d,b/c,b/d}\}$}italic_A = { italic_a / italic_c , italic_a / italic_d , italic_b / italic_c , italic_b / italic_d }.

However, the equality does not need to hold here. Indeed, note for example that intâ¡([155..161]/[9..11])=[16..16]intdelimited-[]155..161delimited-[]9..11delimited-[]16..16\operatorname{int}([155..161]/[9..11])=[16..16]roman_int ( [ 155..161 ] / [ 9..11 ] ) = [ 16..16 ], whereas for A={155/9,155/11,161/9A=\{155/9,155/11,161/9italic_A = { 155 / 9 , 155 / 11 , 161 / 9, 161/11}161/11\}161 / 11 } we have âŒˆminâ¡(A)âŒ‰=15minğ´15\left\lceil\operatorname{min}(A)\right\rceil=15âŒˆ roman_min ( italic_A ) âŒ‰ = 15 and âŒŠmaxâ¡(A)âŒ‹=17maxğ´17\left\lfloor\operatorname{max}(A)\right\rfloor=17âŒŠ roman_max ( italic_A ) âŒ‹ = 17. The problem is that the value 16 is obtained by dividing 160 by 10 and none of these two values is an interval bound.

This complication can be solved by preprocessing the interval [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ] so that its bounds are actual divisors of an element of [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ]. First, we look for the least câ€²âˆˆ[c..d]c^{\prime}\in[c..d]italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_c . . italic_d ] such that âˆƒxâˆˆ[a..b]âˆƒuâˆˆğ’µuâ‹…câ€²=x\exists x\in[a..b]\ \exists u\in{\cal Z}\ u\cdot c^{\prime}=xâˆƒ italic_x âˆˆ [ italic_a . . italic_b ] âˆƒ italic_u âˆˆ caligraphic_Z italic_u â‹… italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x. Using a case analysis, the latter property can be established without search. Suppose for example that a>0ğ‘0a>0italic_a > 0 and c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0. In this case, if câ€²â‹…âŒŠb/câ€²âŒ‹â‰¥aâ‹…superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘c^{\prime}\cdot\lfloor b/c^{\prime}\rfloor\geq aitalic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… âŒŠ italic_b / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŒ‹ â‰¥ italic_a, then câ€²superscriptğ‘â€²c^{\prime}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has the required property. Similarly, we look for the largest dâ€²âˆˆ[c..d]d^{\prime}\in[c..d]italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_c . . italic_d ] for which an analogous condition holds. Now int([a..b]/[c..d])=[âŒˆmin(A)âŒ‰..âŒŠmax(A)âŒ‹]\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])=[\lceil\operatorname{min}(A)\rceil..\lfloor\operatorname{max}(A)\rfloor]roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) = [ âŒˆ roman_min ( italic_A ) âŒ‰ . . âŒŠ roman_max ( italic_A ) âŒ‹ ], where A={a/câ€²,a/dâ€²,b/câ€²,b/dâ€²}ğ´ğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘‘â€²A=\{a/c^{\prime},a/d^{\prime},b/c^{\prime},b/d^{\prime}\}italic_A = { italic_a / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a / italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b / italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }.

In view of this auxiliary computation (in case when 0âˆ‰[c..d]0\not\in[c..d]0 âˆ‰ [ italic_c . . italic_d ]) we shall introduce in Section 10 a modified division operation with a more direct implementation.

Exponentiation

The intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) closure of the interval exponentiation is straightforward to implement by distinguishing the following cases.

Case 1. Suppose nğ‘›nitalic_n is odd. Then

int([a..b]n)=[an..bn].\operatorname{int}([a..b]^{n})=[a^{n}..\>b^{n}].roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . . italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .

Case 2. Suppose nğ‘›nitalic_n is even and 0â‰¤a0ğ‘0\leq a0 â‰¤ italic_a. Then

int([a..b]n)=[an..bn].\operatorname{int}([a..b]^{n})=[a^{n}..\>b^{n}].roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . . italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .

Case 3. Suppose nğ‘›nitalic_n is even and bâ‰¤0ğ‘0b\leq 0italic_b â‰¤ 0. Then

int([a..b]n)=[bn..an].\operatorname{int}([a..b]^{n})=[b^{n}..\>a^{n}].roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . . italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .

Case 4. Suppose nğ‘›nitalic_n is even and a<0ğ‘0a<0italic_a < 0 and 0<b0ğ‘0<b0 < italic_b. Then

int([a..b]n)=[0..max(an,bn)].\operatorname{int}([a..b]^{n})=[0..\operatorname{max}(a^{n},b^{n})].roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ 0 . . roman_max ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] .

3.3 Correctness Lemma

Given now an extended arithmetic expression sğ‘ sitalic_s each variable of which ranges over an integer interval, we define intâ¡(s)intğ‘ \operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ) as the integer interval or the set ğ’µğ’µ{\cal Z}caligraphic_Z obtained by systematically replacing each function symbol by the application of the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) operation to the corresponding integer set operation. For example, for the extended arithmetic expression s:=(y2â‹…z4)/(x2â‹…u5)3assignğ‘ 3â‹…superscriptğ‘¦2superscriptğ‘§4â‹…superscriptğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘¢5s:=\sqrt[3]{(y^{2}\cdot z^{4})/(x^{2}\cdot u^{5})}italic_s := nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) / ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG of (2) we have

intâ¡(s)=intâ¡(intâ¡(intâ¡(Y2)â‹…intâ¡(Z4))/intâ¡(intâ¡(X2)â‹…intâ¡(U5))3),intğ‘ int3intâ‹…intsuperscriptğ‘Œ2intsuperscriptğ‘4intâ‹…intsuperscriptğ‘‹2intsuperscriptğ‘ˆ5\operatorname{int}(s)=\operatorname{int}(\sqrt[3]{\operatorname{int}(\operatorname{int}(Y^{2})\cdot\operatorname{int}(Z^{4}))/\operatorname{int}(\operatorname{int}(X^{2})\cdot\operatorname{int}(U^{5}))}),roman_int ( italic_s ) = roman_int ( nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG roman_int ( roman_int ( italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‹… roman_int ( italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) / roman_int ( roman_int ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‹… roman_int ( italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG ) ,

where we assume that xğ‘¥xitalic_x ranges over Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, etc.

The discussion in the previous subsection shows how to compute intâ¡(s)intğ‘ \operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ) given an extended arithmetic expression sğ‘ sitalic_s and the integer interval domains of its variables.

The following lemma is crucial for our considerations. It is a counterpart of the so-called â€˜Fundamental Theorem of Interval Arithmeticâ€™ established in [17]. Because we deal here with the integer domains an additional assumption is needed to establish the desired conclusion.

Lemma 3.2 (Correctness)

Let sğ‘ sitalic_s be an extended arithmetic expression with the variables x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Assume that each variable xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of sğ‘ sitalic_s ranges over an integer interval Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Choose aiâˆˆXisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–a_{i}\in X_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for iâˆˆ[1..n]i\in[1..n]italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] and denote by sâ¢(a1,â€¦,an)ğ‘ subscriptğ‘1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›s(a_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n})italic_s ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) the result of replacing in sğ‘ sitalic_s each occurrence of a variable xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Suppose that each subexpression of sâ¢(a1,â€¦,an)ğ‘ subscriptğ‘1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›s(a_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n})italic_s ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) evaluates to an integer. Then the result of evaluating sâ¢(a1,â€¦,an)ğ‘ subscriptğ‘1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›s(a_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n})italic_s ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is an element of intâ¡(s)normal-intğ‘ \operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ).

Proof.Â The proof follows by a straightforward induction on the structure of sğ‘ sitalic_s.

â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

4 An Intermezzo: Constraint Propagation for Linear Constraints

Even though we focus here on arithmetic constraints on integer intervals, it is helpful to realize that the integer interval arithmetic is also useful to define in a succinct way the well-known rules for constraint propagation for linear constraints (studied in detail in [14]). To this end consider first a constraint Î£i=1nâ¢aiâ‹…xi=bâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}=broman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b, where nâ‰¥0ğ‘›0n\geq 0italic_n â‰¥ 0, a1,â€¦,ansubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›a_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are non-zero integers, x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different variables, and bğ‘bitalic_b is an integer. We rewrite this constraint nğ‘›nitalic_n times, each time isolating one variable, to obtain an extended arithmetic expression for each variable xjsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To each of these extended arithmetic expressions we apply then the intint\operatorname{int}roman_int operation of SubsectionÂ 3.3, which yields an update for the domain of the corresponding variable xjsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To reason about this procedure we can use the following rule parametrized by jâˆˆ[1..n]j\in[1..n]italic_j âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ]:

LINEAR EQUALITY

âŸ¨Î£i=1nâ¢aiâ‹…xi=b;x1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xjâˆˆDj,â€¦,xnâˆˆDnâŸ©âŸ¨Î£i=1nâ¢aiâ‹…xi=b;x1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xjâˆˆDjâ€²,â€¦,xnâˆˆDnâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ·1â€¦formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ·ğ‘—â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ·1â€¦formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›\frac{\langle\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}=b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}{\langle\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}=b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

where Djâ€²:=Djâˆ©intâ¡((bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…xi)/aj)D^{\prime}_{j}:=D_{j}\cap\operatorname{int}\Big{(}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})/a_{j}\Big{)}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Note that by virtue of Note 3.1

Djâ€²=Djâˆ©(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢intâ¡(aiâ‹…Di))/aj.D^{\prime}_{j}=D_{j}\cap(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}\operatorname{int}(a_{i}\cdot D_{i}))/a_{j}.italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

To see that this rule preserves equivalence, first note that all our reduction rules compute the domain updates via intersection with the original domain, preventing that domains are extended by their application. Further, suppose that for some d1âˆˆD1,â€¦,dnâˆˆDnformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›d_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}\in D_{n}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have Î£i=1nâ¢aiâ‹…di=bâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot d_{i}=broman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b. Then for jâˆˆ[1..n]j\in[1..n]italic_j âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] we have

dj=(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…di)/ajd_{j}=(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot d_{i})/a_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

which by the Correctness Lemma 3.2 implies that

djâˆˆintâ¡((bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…xi)/aj),d_{j}\in\operatorname{int}\Big{(}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})/a_{j}\Big{)},italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_int ( ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

i.e., djâˆˆDjâ€²subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—d_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Next, consider a constraint Î£i=1nâ¢aiâ‹…xiâ‰¤bâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}\leq broman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_b, where a1,â€¦,an,x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›a_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},a_{n},x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bğ‘bitalic_b are as above. To reason about it we can use the following rule parametrized by jâˆˆ[1..n]j\in[1..n]italic_j âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ]:

LINEAR INEQUALITY

âŸ¨Î£i=1nâ¢aiâ‹…xiâ‰¤b;x1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xjâˆˆDj,â€¦,xnâˆˆDnâŸ©âŸ¨Î£i=1nâ¢aiâ‹…xiâ‰¤b;x1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xjâˆˆDjâ€²,â€¦,xnâˆˆDnâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ·1â€¦formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ·ğ‘—â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ·1â€¦formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›\frac{\langle\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}\leq b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}{\langle\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}\leq b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_b ; where Djâ€²:=Djâˆ©(â‰¤int(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}aiâ‹…xi)/aj)D^{\prime}_{j}:=D_{j}\cap(^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})/a_{j})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© ( start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

To see that this rule preserves equivalence, suppose that for some d1âˆˆD1,â€¦,dnâˆˆDnformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›d_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}\in D_{n}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have Î£i=1nâ¢aiâ‹…diâ‰¤bâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘\Sigma_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot d_{i}\leq broman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_b. Then ajâ‹…djâ‰¤bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…dia_{j}\cdot d_{j}\leq b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot d_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the Correctness Lemma 3.2

bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…diâˆˆintâ¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…xi),b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot d_{i}\in\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i}),italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

so by definition

ajâ‹…djâˆˆâ‰¤intâ¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…xi)a_{j}\cdot d_{j}\in^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

and consequently

djâˆˆâ‰¤intâ¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…xi)/aj.d_{j}\in^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})/a_{j}.italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

This implies that djâˆˆDjâ€²subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—d_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

As an alternative to evaluating intâ¡(Î£iâˆˆ[1..n]âˆ’{j}â¢aiâ‹…xi)\operatorname{int}(\Sigma_{i\in[1..n]-\{j\}}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})roman_int ( roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] - { italic_j } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on every application of the LINEAR EQUALITY and LINEAR INEQUALITY rules, we could maintain the interval intâ¡(Î£1nâ¢aiâ‹…xi)intâ‹…superscriptsubscriptÎ£1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\operatorname{int}(\Sigma_{1}^{n}a_{i}\cdot x_{i})roman_int ( roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in an auxiliary variable, and subtract intâ¡(ajâ‹…xj)intâ‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\operatorname{int}(a_{j}\cdot x_{j})roman_int ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) from it. This corresponds to the two-step propagation described in [14]. If changes to Djsubscriptğ·ğ‘—D_{j}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are propagated back to the auxiliary variable, this does not affect the reduction achieved by the subsequent applications of the rules, while the number of interval arithmetic operations involved in the application of a rule becomes constant, instead of linear in the number nğ‘›nitalic_n of variables.

5 Constraint Propagation: Direct Approach

As a first approach to constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals, we propose to use the constraints directly, in their original form. This is an extension of the approach of SectionÂ 4 from linear constraints to general arithmetic constraints, and entails that these constraints are rewritten to isolate all occurrences of each variable. The resulting extended arithmetic expressions are then evaluated to obtain updates for the isolated variables.

The following example illustrates this approach. Consider the constraint

x3â‹…yâˆ’xâ‰¤40â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦ğ‘¥40x^{3}\cdot y-x\leq 40italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y - italic_x â‰¤ 40

and the ranges xâˆˆ[1..100]ğ‘¥delimited-[]1..100x\in[1..100]italic_x âˆˆ [ 1..100 ] and yâˆˆ[1..100]ğ‘¦delimited-[]1..100y\in[1..100]italic_y âˆˆ [ 1..100 ]. We can rewrite it as

xâ‰¤âŒŠ(40+x)/y3âŒ‹ğ‘¥340ğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\leq\left\lfloor\sqrt[3]{(40+x)/y}\right\rflooritalic_x â‰¤ âŒŠ nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG ( 40 + italic_x ) / italic_y end_ARG âŒ‹ (3)

since xğ‘¥xitalic_x assumes integer values. The maximum value the expression on the right-hand side can take is âŒŠ1403âŒ‹3140\left\lfloor\sqrt[3]{140}\right\rfloorâŒŠ nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 140 end_ARG âŒ‹, so we conclude xâ‰¤5ğ‘¥5x\leq 5italic_x â‰¤ 5. By reusing (3), now with the information that xâˆˆ[1..5]ğ‘¥delimited-[]1..5x\in[1..5]italic_x âˆˆ [ 1..5 ], we conclude that the maximum value the expression on the right-hand side of (3) can take is actually âŒŠ453âŒ‹345\left\lfloor\sqrt[3]{45}\right\rfloorâŒŠ nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 45 end_ARG âŒ‹, from which it follows that xâ‰¤3ğ‘¥3x\leq 3italic_x â‰¤ 3.

In the case of yğ‘¦yitalic_y we can isolate it by rewriting the original constraint as yâ‰¤40/x3+1/x2ğ‘¦40superscriptğ‘¥31superscriptğ‘¥2y\leq 40/x^{3}+1/x^{2}italic_y â‰¤ 40 / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from which it follows that yâ‰¤41ğ‘¦41y\leq 41italic_y â‰¤ 41, since by assumption xâ‰¥1ğ‘¥1x\geq 1italic_x â‰¥ 1. So we could reduce the domain of xğ‘¥xitalic_x to [1..3]delimited-[]1..3[1..3][ 1..3 ] and the domain of yğ‘¦yitalic_y to [1..41]delimited-[]1..41[1..41][ 1..41 ]. This interval reduction is optimal, since x=1,y=41formulae-sequenceğ‘¥1ğ‘¦41x=1,y=41italic_x = 1 , italic_y = 41 and x=3,y=1formulae-sequenceğ‘¥3ğ‘¦1x=3,y=1italic_x = 3 , italic_y = 1 are both solutions to the original constraint x3â‹…yâˆ’xâ‰¤40â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦ğ‘¥40x^{3}\cdot y-x\leq 40italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y - italic_x â‰¤ 40. So rewriting the constraint as xâ‰¥x3â‹…yâˆ’40ğ‘¥â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦40x\geq x^{3}\cdot y-40italic_x â‰¥ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y - 40 does not yield a new lower bound for xğ‘¥xitalic_x.

More formally, consider a polynomial constraint Î£i=1mâ¢mi=bsubscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘šğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘\Sigma^{m}_{i=1}m_{i}=broman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b where m>0ğ‘š0m>0italic_m > 0, no monomial misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an integer, the power products of the monomials are pairwise different, and bğ‘bitalic_b is an integer. Suppose that x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are its variables ordered w.r.t.Â â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º.

Select a non-integer monomial mlsubscriptğ‘šğ‘™m_{l}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and assume it is of the form

aâ‹…y1n1â‹…â€¦â‹…yknk,â‹…ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘›1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜a\cdot y_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot y_{k}^{n_{k}},italic_a â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… â€¦ â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where k>0ğ‘˜0k>0italic_k > 0, y1,â€¦,yksubscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},y_{k}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are different variables ordered w.r.t.Â â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º, ağ‘aitalic_a is a non-zero integer and n1,â€¦,nksubscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},n_{k}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positive integers. So each yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT variable equals to some variable in {x1,â€¦,xn}subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\{{x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Suppose that ypsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘y_{p}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equals to xjsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We introduce the following proof rule:

POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY

âŸ¨Î£i=1nâ¢mi=b;x1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xjâˆˆDj,â€¦,xnâˆˆDnâŸ©âŸ¨Î£i=1nâ¢mi=b;x1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xjâˆˆDjâ€²,â€¦,xnâˆˆDnâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘›ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ·1â€¦formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ·ğ‘—â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘›ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ·1â€¦formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›\frac{\langle\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}m_{i}=b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}{\langle\Sigma^{n}_{i=1}m_{i}=b\ ;\ x_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}\in D_{n}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

To see that this rule preserves equivalence, choose some d1âˆˆD1,â€¦,dnâˆˆDnformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›d_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}\in D_{n}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To simplify the notation, given an extended arithmetic expression tğ‘¡titalic_t denote by tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the result of evaluating tğ‘¡titalic_t after each occurrence of a variable xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is replaced by disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Suppose that Î£i=1mâ¢miâ€²=bsuperscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘–ğ‘\Sigma_{i=1}^{m}m^{\prime}_{i}=broman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b. Then

djnpâ‹…sâ€²=bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢miâ€²,d_{j}^{n_{p}}\cdot s^{\prime}=b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m^{\prime}_{i},italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

so by the Correctness Lemma 3.2 applied to bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢miâ€²b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m^{\prime}_{i}italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and to sğ‘ sitalic_s

djnpâˆˆintâ¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢mi)/intâ¡(s).d_{j}^{n_{p}}\in\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/\operatorname{int}(s).italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_int ( italic_s ) .

Hence

and consequently

djâˆˆintâ¡(Djâˆ©intâ¡((bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢mi)/s)np)d_{j}\in\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{\operatorname{int}\left(({b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i}})/s\right)}\ \right)italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_int ( ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_s ) end_ARG )

i.e., djâˆˆDjâ€²subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—d_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Note that we do not apply intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) to the outcome of the root extraction operation. For even npsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{p}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT this means that the second operand of the intersection can be a union of two intervals, instead of a single interval. To see why this is desirable, consider the constraint x2âˆ’y=0superscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘¦0x^{2}-y=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_y = 0 in the presence of ranges xâˆˆ[0..10]ğ‘¥delimited-[]0..10x\in[0..10]italic_x âˆˆ [ 0..10 ], yâˆˆ[25..100]ğ‘¦delimited-[]25..100y\in[25..100]italic_y âˆˆ [ 25..100 ]. Using the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) closure of the root extraction we would not be able to update the lower bound of xğ‘¥xitalic_x to 5.

Next, consider a polynomial constraint Î£i=1mâ¢miâ‰¤b.subscriptsuperscriptÎ£ğ‘šğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘\Sigma^{m}_{i=1}m_{i}\leq b.roman_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_b . Below we adopt the assumptions and notation used when defining the POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule. To formulate the appropriate rule we stipulate that for the extended arithmetic expressions sğ‘ sitalic_s and tğ‘¡titalic_t

int((â‰¤s)/t):=â‰¥Qâˆ©â‰¤Q,\operatorname{int}((^{\leq}s)/t)\ :=\ ^{\geq}Q\cap\ ^{\leq}Q,roman_int ( ( start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s ) / italic_t ) := start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q âˆ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q ,

with Q=(â‰¤int(s))/int(t)Q=(^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(s))/\operatorname{int}(t)italic_Q = ( start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_s ) ) / roman_int ( italic_t ).

To reason about this constraint we use the following rule:

POLYNOMIAL INEQUALITY
