where Djâ€²:=intâ¡(Djâˆ©int((bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}mi)â‰¤/s)np)D^{\prime}_{j}:=\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{\operatorname{int}\left({}^{\leq}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/s\right)}\ \right)italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_int ( start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_s ) end_ARG ), with s:=aâ‹…y1n1â‹…â€¦â‹…ypâˆ’1npâˆ’1â‹…yp+1np+1â¢â€¦â‹…yknkassignğ‘ â‹…â‹…ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘›1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜s:=a\cdot y_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot y_{p-1}^{n_{p-1}}\cdot y_{p+1}^{n_{p+1}}\mbox{$\ldots$}\cdot y_{k}^{n_{k}}italic_s := italic_a â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… â€¦ â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

To prove that this rule preserves equivalence, choose some d1âˆˆD1,â€¦,dnâˆˆDnformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›d_{1}\in D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},d_{n}\in D_{n}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As above given an extended arithmetic expression tğ‘¡titalic_t we denote by tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the result of evaluating tğ‘¡titalic_t when each occurrence of a variable xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in tğ‘¡titalic_t is replaced by disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Suppose that Î£i=1mâ¢miâ€²â‰¤bsuperscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘–ğ‘\Sigma_{i=1}^{m}m^{\prime}_{i}\leq broman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_b. Then

djnpâ‹…sâ€²â‰¤bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢miâ€².d_{j}^{n_{p}}\cdot s^{\prime}\leq b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m^{\prime}_{i}.italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

By the Correctness Lemma 3.2

bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢miâ€²âˆˆintâ¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢mi),b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m^{\prime}_{i}\in\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i}),italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

so by definition

djnpâ‹…sâ€²âˆˆâ‰¤intâ¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢mi).d_{j}^{n_{p}}\cdot s^{\prime}\in^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i}).italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

Hence by the definition of the division operation on the sets of integers

djnpâˆˆâ‰¤intâ¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢mi)/intâ¡(s)d_{j}^{n_{p}}\in^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/\operatorname{int}(s)italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_int ( italic_s )

Consequently

djâˆˆintâ‰¤â¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢mi)/intâ¡(s)np.d_{j}\in\sqrt[n_{p}]{{}^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})/\operatorname{int}(s)}.italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_int ( italic_s ) end_ARG .

This implies that djâˆˆDjâ€²subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—d_{j}\in D^{\prime}_{j}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Note that the set intâ‰¤â¡(bâˆ’Î£iâˆˆ[1..m]âˆ’{l}â¢mi){}^{\leq}\operatorname{int}(b-\Sigma_{i\in[1..m]-\{{l}\}}m_{i})start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( italic_b - roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which occurs when the expression for Djâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—D^{\prime}_{j}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is expanded according to the above definition of int((â‰¤s)/t)\operatorname{int}((^{\leq}s)/t)roman_int ( ( start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s ) / italic_t ), is not an interval. So to properly implement this rule we need to extend the implementation of the division operation discussed in Subsection 3.2 to the case when the numerator is an extended interval.

If the sum of the intervals associated with each of the monomials in a polynomial constraint is maintained in an auxiliary variable, as we discussed at the end of SectionÂ 4 for linear constraints,Â then the rules can be applied using a constant number of interval additions. However, interval division is not the inverse operation of interval multiplication, so the same technique cannot be applied to monomials, and the number of multiplications and exponentiations will be linear in the size of the monomial sğ‘ sitalic_s.

In an optimized version of the direct approach we simplify the fractions of two polynomials by splitting the division over addition and subtraction and by dividing out common powers of variables and greatest common divisors of the constant factors. Subsequently, fractions whose denominators have identical power products are added. We used this optimization in the initial example by simplifying (40+x)/x340ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥3(40+x)/x^{3}( 40 + italic_x ) / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 40/x3+1/x240superscriptğ‘¥31superscriptğ‘¥240/x^{3}+1/x^{2}40 / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 / italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The reader may check that without this simplification step we can only deduce that yâ‰¤43ğ‘¦43y\leq 43italic_y â‰¤ 43.

To provide details of this optimization, given two monomials sğ‘ sitalic_s and tğ‘¡titalic_t, we denote by

[s/t]delimited-[]ğ‘ ğ‘¡[s/t][ italic_s / italic_t ]

the result of performing this simplification operation on sğ‘ sitalic_s and tğ‘¡titalic_t. For example, [(2â‹…x3â‹…y)/(4â‹…x2)]delimited-[]â‹…2superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦â‹…4superscriptğ‘¥2[(2\cdot x^{3}\cdot y)/(4\cdot x^{2})][ ( 2 â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y ) / ( 4 â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] equals (xâ‹…y)/2â‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦2(x\cdot y)/2( italic_x â‹… italic_y ) / 2, whereas [(4â‹…x3â‹…y)/(2â‹…y2)]delimited-[]â‹…4superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦â‹…2superscriptğ‘¦2[(4\cdot x^{3}\cdot y)/(2\cdot y^{2})][ ( 4 â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y ) / ( 2 â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] equals (2â‹…x3)/yâ‹…2superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦(2\cdot x^{3})/y( 2 â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) / italic_y.

Because the validity of the simplification depends on the sign of the denominator, we assume that the domains of the variables y1,â€¦,ypâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘1y_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},y_{p-1}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, yp+1,â€¦,ynsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›y_{p+1},\mbox{$\ldots$},y_{n}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of mlsubscriptğ‘šğ‘™m_{l}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT do not contain 0. For a monomial sğ‘ sitalic_s involving variables ranging over the integer intervals that do not contain 0, the set intâ¡(s)intğ‘ \operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ) either contains only positive numbers or only negative numbers. In the first case we write signâ¡(s)=+signğ‘ \operatorname{sign}(s)=+roman_sign ( italic_s ) = + and in the second case we write signâ¡(s)=âˆ’signğ‘ \operatorname{sign}(s)=-roman_sign ( italic_s ) = -.

The new domain of the variable xjsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the POLYNOMIAL INEQUALITY rule is defined using two sequences m0â€²â¢â€¦â¢mnâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘š0â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘›â€²m_{0}^{\prime}...m_{n}^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and s0â€²â¢â€¦â¢snâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 0â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›â€²s_{0}^{\prime}...s_{n}^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of extended arithmetic expressions such that

m0â€²/s0â€²=[b/s]â¢andâ¢miâ€²/siâ€²=âˆ’[mi/s]â¢forÂ iâˆˆ[1..m].superscriptsubscriptğ‘š0â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ 0â€²delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘ andsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–â€²delimited-[]subscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘ forÂ iâˆˆ[1..m].m_{0}^{\prime}/s_{0}^{\prime}=[b/s]\ \textrm{and}\ m_{i}^{\prime}/s_{i}^{\prime}=-[m_{i}/s]\ \textrm{for $i\in[1..m]$.}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_b / italic_s ] and italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - [ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_s ] for italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_m ] .

Let S:={siâ€²âˆ£iâˆˆ[0..m]âˆ’{l}}S:=\{s_{i}^{\prime}\mid i\in[0..m]-\{{l}\}\}italic_S := { italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_i âˆˆ [ 0 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } } and for an extended arithmetic expression tâˆˆSğ‘¡ğ‘†t\in Sitalic_t âˆˆ italic_S let It:={iâˆˆ[0..m]âˆ’{l}âˆ£siâ€²=t}I_{t}:=\{i\in[0..m]-\{{l}\}\mid s_{i}^{\prime}=t\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { italic_i âˆˆ [ 0 . . italic_m ] - { italic_l } âˆ£ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_t }. We denote then by ptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡p_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the polynomial âˆ‘iâˆˆItmiâ€²subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ¼ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–â€²\sum_{i\in I_{t}}{m_{i}^{\prime}}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The new domains are then defined by

Djâ€²:=intâ¡(Djâˆ©intâ‰¤â¡(Î£tâˆˆSâ¢ptâŠ˜t)np)assignsubscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—intsubscriptğ·ğ‘—subscriptğ‘›ğ‘superscriptintâŠ˜subscriptÎ£ğ‘¡ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡D^{\prime}_{j}:=\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{{}^{\leq}\operatorname{int}\left(\Sigma_{t\in S}\ p_{t}\oslash t\right)}\ \right)italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ˜ italic_t ) end_ARG )

if signâ¡(s)=+signğ‘ \operatorname{sign}(s)=+roman_sign ( italic_s ) = +, and by

Djâ€²:=intâ¡(Djâˆ©intâ‰¥â¡(Î£tâˆˆSâ¢ptâŠ˜t)np)assignsubscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—intsubscriptğ·ğ‘—subscriptğ‘›ğ‘superscriptintâŠ˜subscriptÎ£ğ‘¡ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡D^{\prime}_{j}:=\operatorname{int}\left(D_{j}\cap\sqrt[n_{p}]{{}^{\geq}\operatorname{int}\left(\Sigma_{t\in S}\ p_{t}\oslash t\right)}\ \right)italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© nth-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_int ( roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ˜ italic_t ) end_ARG )

if signâ¡(s)=âˆ’signğ‘ \operatorname{sign}(s)=-roman_sign ( italic_s ) = -. Here the intâ¡(s)intğ‘ \operatorname{int}(s)roman_int ( italic_s ) notation used in the Correctness Lemma 3.2 is extended to expressions involving the division operator âŠ˜âŠ˜\oslashâŠ˜ on real intervals in the obvious way. We define the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) operator applied to a bounded set of reals, as produced by the division and addition operators in the above two expressions for Djâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘—D^{\prime}_{j}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to denote the smallest interval of reals containing that set.

Returning again to the discussion of the two-step propagation technique of [14], which we started at the end of SectionÂ 4, note that in this case, the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) operation is applied after removing the common power products. For this reason, there is no straightforward way to calculate intâ¡(Î£tâˆˆSâ¢ptâŠ˜t)intâŠ˜subscriptÎ£ğ‘¡ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡\operatorname{int}(\Sigma_{t\in S}\ p_{t}\oslash t)roman_int ( roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ˜ italic_t ) from the sum of all intervals associated with the monomials of a polynomial constraint.

6 Constraint Propagation: Partial Decomposition

As a second approach to constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals, we limit our attention to a special type of polynomial constraints, namely the ones of the form sâ¢oâ¢pâ¢bğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘s\ op\ bitalic_s italic_o italic_p italic_b, where sğ‘ sitalic_s is a polynomial in which each variable occurs at most once and where bğ‘bitalic_b is an integer. We call such a constraint a simple polynomial constraint. By introducing auxiliary variables that are equated with appropriate monomials we can decompose any polynomial constraint into a sequence of simple polynomial constraints. This allows us also to compute the integer interval domains of the auxiliary variable from the integer interval domains of the original variables. We apply then to the simple polynomial constraints the rules introduced in the previous section.

To see that the restriction to simple polynomial constraints can make a difference consider the constraint

100â¢xâ‹…yâˆ’10â¢yâ‹…z=212,â‹…100ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â‹…10ğ‘¦ğ‘§212100x\cdot y-10y\cdot z=212,100 italic_x â‹… italic_y - 10 italic_y â‹… italic_z = 212 ,

and ranges x,y,zâˆˆ[1..9]ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§delimited-[]1..9x,y,z\in[1..9]italic_x , italic_y , italic_z âˆˆ [ 1..9 ]. We rewrite it into the sequence

u=xâ‹…y,v=yâ‹…z, 100â¢uâˆ’10â¢v=212,formulae-sequenceğ‘¢â‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦formulae-sequenceğ‘£â‹…ğ‘¦ğ‘§100ğ‘¢10ğ‘£212u=x\cdot y,\ v=y\cdot z,\ 100u-10v=212,italic_u = italic_x â‹… italic_y , italic_v = italic_y â‹… italic_z , 100 italic_u - 10 italic_v = 212 ,

where u,vğ‘¢ğ‘£u,vitalic_u , italic_v are auxiliary variables, each with the domain [1..81]delimited-[]1..81[1..81][ 1..81 ].

It is easy to check that the POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule introduced in the previous section does not yield any domain reduction when applied to the original constraint 100â¢xâ‹…yâˆ’10â¢yâ‹…z=212â‹…100ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â‹…10ğ‘¦ğ‘§212100x\cdot y-10y\cdot z=212100 italic_x â‹… italic_y - 10 italic_y â‹… italic_z = 212. In the presence of the discussed optimization the domain of xğ‘¥xitalic_x gets reduced to [1..3]delimited-[]1..3[1..3][ 1..3 ].

However, if we repeatedly apply the POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule to the simple polynomial constraint 100â¢uâˆ’10â¢v=212100ğ‘¢10ğ‘£212100u-10v=212100 italic_u - 10 italic_v = 212, we eventually reduce the domain of uğ‘¢uitalic_u to the empty set (since this constraint has no integer solution in the ranges u,vâˆˆ[1..81]ğ‘¢ğ‘£delimited-[]1..81u,v\in[1..81]italic_u , italic_v âˆˆ [ 1..81 ]) and consequently can conclude that the original constraint 100â¢xâ‹…yâˆ’10â¢yâ‹…z=212â‹…100ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â‹…10ğ‘¦ğ‘§212100x\cdot y-10y\cdot z=212100 italic_x â‹… italic_y - 10 italic_y â‹… italic_z = 212 has no solution in the ranges x,y,zâˆˆ[1..9]ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§delimited-[]1..9x,y,z\in[1..9]italic_x , italic_y , italic_z âˆˆ [ 1..9 ], without performing any search. Note that this effect still occurs if we replace one occurrence of yğ‘¦yitalic_y by a fresh variable with the same domain.

As noted in [8], decomposing constraints also prevents the evaluation of subexpressions whose domains did not change, which may reduce the number of interval arithmetic operations performed during constraint propagation. In our case duplicate occurrences of variables are removed, so the reduction rules additionally become idempotent. However, this can be seen as a side-effect: rules still update variables that they depend on, only now this update is indirect, through other variables.

Consider for example the constraint x3â‹…yâˆ’xâ‰¤40â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦ğ‘¥40x^{3}\cdot y-x\leq 40italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y - italic_x â‰¤ 40 of SectionÂ 5. If we rewrite this constraint as uâˆ’xâ‰¤40ğ‘¢ğ‘¥40u-x\leq 40italic_u - italic_x â‰¤ 40, with u=x3â‹…yğ‘¢â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦u=x^{3}\cdot yitalic_u = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y and x,yâˆˆ[1..100]ğ‘¥ğ‘¦delimited-[]1..100x,y\in[1..100]italic_x , italic_y âˆˆ [ 1..100 ], then via uâ‰¤x+40ğ‘¢ğ‘¥40u\leq x+40italic_u â‰¤ italic_x + 40 we can set the upper bound for uğ‘¢uitalic_u to 140. Via x=u/y3ğ‘¥3ğ‘¢ğ‘¦x=\sqrt[3]{u/y}italic_x = nth-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG italic_u / italic_y end_ARG we can then set the upper for xğ‘¥xitalic_x to 5. This allows us to set the upper bound for uğ‘¢uitalic_u to 45 via uâ‰¤x+40ğ‘¢ğ‘¥40u\leq x+40italic_u â‰¤ italic_x + 40, etc. From this point of view the auxiliary variables, and the idempotence that they entail, can be seen as an optimization that prevents the evaluation of expressions that will not lead to further domain updates.

7 Constraint Propagation: Full Decomposition

In this third approach we focus on a small set of â€˜atomicâ€™ arithmetic constraints. We call an arithmetic constraint atomic if it is in one of the following two forms:

  • â€¢

    a linear constraint,

  • â€¢

    xâ‹…y=zâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§x\cdot y=zitalic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z.

Using appropriate transformation rules involving auxiliary variables we can decompose any arithmetic constraint to a sequence of atomic arithmetic constraints, similar to the decomposition of linear constraints into constraints on groups of three variables in clp(FD) [8]. In this transformation, as with partial decomposition, the auxiliary variables are equated with monomials, so we can easily compute their domains.

We explained already in Section 4 how to reason about linear constraints. For a treatment of disequalities see, e.g., [14, 20]. Next, we focus on the reasoning for the multiplication constraint xâ‹…y=zâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§x\cdot y=zitalic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z in the presence of the non-empty ranges xâˆˆDxğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥x\in D_{x}italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, yâˆˆDyğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦y\in D_{y}italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and zâˆˆDzğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§z\in D_{z}italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To this end we introduce the following three domain reduction rules:

MULTIPLICATION 1

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâ€²âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘§â€²\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}^{\prime}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

MULTIPLICATION 2

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDxâ€²,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥â€²formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x}^{\prime},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

MULTIPLICATION 3

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDyâ€²,zâˆˆDzâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦â€²ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}^{\prime},z\in D_{z}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

where Dzâ€²:=Dzâˆ©intâ¡(Dxâ‹…Dy)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘§â€²subscriptğ·ğ‘§intâ‹…subscriptğ·ğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¦D_{z}^{\prime}:=D_{z}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{x}\cdot D_{y})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), Dxâ€²:=Dxâˆ©intâ¡(Dz/Dy)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥â€²subscriptğ·ğ‘¥intsubscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¦D_{x}^{\prime}:=D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and Dyâ€²:=Dyâˆ©intâ¡(Dz/Dx)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦â€²subscriptğ·ğ‘¦intsubscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¥D_{y}^{\prime}:=D_{y}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{x})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

The way we defined the multiplication and the division of the integer intervals ensures that the MULTIPLICATION rules 1,2, and 3 are equivalence preserving. Consider for example the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule. Take some aâˆˆDx,bâˆˆDyformulae-sequenceğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘¦a\in D_{x},b\in D_{y}italic_a âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and câˆˆDzğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘§c\in D_{z}italic_c âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that aâ‹…b=câ‹…ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘a\cdot b=citalic_a â‹… italic_b = italic_c. Then aâˆˆ{xâˆˆğ’µâˆ£âˆƒzâˆˆDzâ¢âˆƒyâˆˆDyâ¢xâ‹…y=z}ğ‘conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’µğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§ğ‘¦â‹…subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§a\in\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}z\in D_{z}\mbox{$\exists$}y\in D_{y}\>x\cdot y=z}\}$}italic_a âˆˆ { italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_Z âˆ£ âˆƒ italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆƒ italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z }, so aâˆˆDz/Dyğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¦a\in D_{z}/D_{y}italic_a âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a fortiori aâˆˆintâ¡(Dz/Dy)ğ‘intsubscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¦a\in\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})italic_a âˆˆ roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Consequently aâˆˆDxâˆ©intâ¡(Dz/Dy)ğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘¥intsubscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¦a\in D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})italic_a âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Because we also have Dxâˆ©intâ¡(Dz/Dy)âŠ†Dxsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥intsubscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¥D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})\subseteq D_{x}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŠ† italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this shows that the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule is equivalence preserving.

The following example shows an interaction between all three MULTIPLICATION rules.

Example 7.1

Consider the CSP

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆ[1..20],yâˆˆ[9..11],zâˆˆ[155..161]âŸ©.delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥delimited-[]1..20formulae-sequenceğ‘¦delimited-[]9..11ğ‘§delimited-[]155..161{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[1..20],y\in[9..11],z\in[155..161]\rangle}.âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ [ 1..20 ] , italic_y âˆˆ [ 9..11 ] , italic_z âˆˆ [ 155..161 ] âŸ© . (4)

To facilitate the reading we underline the modified domains. An application of the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule yields

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆ[16..16]Â¯,yâˆˆ[9..11],zâˆˆ[155..161]âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥Â¯delimited-[]16..16formulae-sequenceğ‘¦delimited-[]9..11ğ‘§delimited-[]155..161{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in\underline{[16..16]},y\in[9..11],z\in[155..161]\rangle}âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ underÂ¯ start_ARG [ 16..16 ] end_ARG , italic_y âˆˆ [ 9..11 ] , italic_z âˆˆ [ 155..161 ] âŸ©

since, as already noted in Subsection 3.2, [155..161]/[9..11])=[16..16][155..161]/[9..11])=[16..16][ 155..161 ] / [ 9..11 ] ) = [ 16..16 ], and [1..20]âˆ©intâ¡([16..16])=[16..16]delimited-[]1..20intdelimited-[]16..16delimited-[]16..16[1..20]\cap\operatorname{int}([16..16])=[16..16][ 1..20 ] âˆ© roman_int ( [ 16..16 ] ) = [ 16..16 ]. Applying now the MULTIPLICATION 3 rule we obtain

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆ[16..16],yâˆˆ[10..10]Â¯,zâˆˆ[155..161]âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥delimited-[]16..16formulae-sequenceğ‘¦Â¯delimited-[]10..10ğ‘§delimited-[]155..161\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[16..16],y\in\underline{[10..10]},z\in[155..161]\rangleâŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ [ 16..16 ] , italic_y âˆˆ underÂ¯ start_ARG [ 10..10 ] end_ARG , italic_z âˆˆ [ 155..161 ] âŸ©

since [155..161]/[16..16]=[10..10]delimited-[]155..161delimited-[]16..16delimited-[]10..10[155..161]/[16..16]=[10..10][ 155..161 ] / [ 16..16 ] = [ 10..10 ] and [9..11]âˆ©intâ¡([10..10])=[10..10]delimited-[]9..11intdelimited-[]10..10delimited-[]10..10[9..11]\cap\operatorname{int}([10..10])=[10..10][ 9..11 ] âˆ© roman_int ( [ 10..10 ] ) = [ 10..10 ]. Next, by the application of the MULTIPLICATION 1 rule we obtain

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆ[16..16],yâˆˆ[10..10],zâˆˆ[160..160]Â¯âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥delimited-[]16..16formulae-sequenceğ‘¦delimited-[]10..10ğ‘§Â¯delimited-[]160..160\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[16..16],y\in[10..10],z\in\underline{[160..160]}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ [ 16..16 ] , italic_y âˆˆ [ 10..10 ] , italic_z âˆˆ underÂ¯ start_ARG [ 160..160 ] end_ARG âŸ©

since [16..16]â‹…[10..10]=[160..160]â‹…delimited-[]16..16delimited-[]10..10delimited-[]160..160[16..16]\cdot[10..10]=[160..160][ 16..16 ] â‹… [ 10..10 ] = [ 160..160 ] and [155..161]âˆ©intâ¡([160..160])=[160..160]delimited-[]155..161intdelimited-[]160..160delimited-[]160..160[155..161]\cap\operatorname{int}([160..160])=[160..160][ 155..161 ] âˆ© roman_int ( [ 160..160 ] ) = [ 160..160 ].

So using all three multiplication rules we could solve the CSP (4). â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Now let us clarify why we did not define the division of the sets of integers Zğ‘Zitalic_Z and Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y by

Z/Y:={z/yâˆˆğ’µâˆ£yâˆˆY,zâˆˆZ,yâ‰ 0}.assignğ‘ğ‘Œconditional-setğ‘§ğ‘¦ğ’µformulae-sequenceğ‘¦ğ‘Œformulae-sequenceğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘¦0Z/Y:=\mbox{$\{{z/y\in{\cal Z}\mid y\in Y,z\in Z,y\neq 0}\}$}.italic_Z / italic_Y := { italic_z / italic_y âˆˆ caligraphic_Z âˆ£ italic_y âˆˆ italic_Y , italic_z âˆˆ italic_Z , italic_y â‰  0 } .

The reason is that in that case for any set of integers Zğ‘Zitalic_Z we would have Z/{0}=âˆ…ğ‘0Z/\mbox{$\{{0}\}$}=\mbox{$\emptyset$}italic_Z / { 0 } = âˆ…. Consequently, if we adopted this definition of the division of the integer intervals, the resulting MULTIPLICATION 2 and 3 rules would not be anymore equivalence preserving. Indeed, consider the CSP

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆ[âˆ’2..1],yâˆˆ[0..0],zâˆˆ[âˆ’8..10]âŸ©.delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥delimited-[]2..1formulae-sequenceğ‘¦delimited-[]0..0ğ‘§delimited-[]8..10\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[-2..1],y\in[0..0],z\in[-8..10]\rangle.âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ [ - 2..1 ] , italic_y âˆˆ [ 0..0 ] , italic_z âˆˆ [ - 8..10 ] âŸ© .

Then we would have [âˆ’8..10]/[0..0]=âˆ…delimited-[]8..10delimited-[]0..0[-8..10]/[0..0]=\mbox{$\emptyset$}[ - 8..10 ] / [ 0..0 ] = âˆ… and consequently by the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule we could conclude

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆâˆ…,yâˆˆ[0..0],zâˆˆ[âˆ’8..10]âŸ©.delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦delimited-[]0..0ğ‘§delimited-[]8..10\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in\mbox{$\emptyset$},y\in[0..0],z\in[-8..10]\rangle.âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ âˆ… , italic_y âˆˆ [ 0..0 ] , italic_z âˆˆ [ - 8..10 ] âŸ© .

So we reached an inconsistent CSP while the original CSP is consistent.

The transformation to atomic constraints can strengthen the reduction. Consider for example the simple constraint

wâ‹…xâ‹…yâ‹…z=24â‹…ğ‘¤ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§24w\cdot x\cdot y\cdot z=24italic_w â‹… italic_x â‹… italic_y â‹… italic_z = 24

with w=4ğ‘¤4w=4italic_w = 4 and x,y,zâˆˆ[1..4]ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§delimited-[]1..4x,y,z\in[1..4]italic_x , italic_y , italic_z âˆˆ [ 1..4 ]. Application of the POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule does not reduce any of the domains, but if we replace the constraint with

uâ‹…v=t,wâ‹…x=u,yâ‹…z=vformulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘¡formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¤ğ‘¥ğ‘¢â‹…ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘£u\cdot v=t,\ w\cdot x=u,\ y\cdot z=vitalic_u â‹… italic_v = italic_t , italic_w â‹… italic_x = italic_u , italic_y â‹… italic_z = italic_v

with additional ranges t=24ğ‘¡24t=24italic_t = 24, uâˆˆ[4..16]ğ‘¢delimited-[]4..16u\in[4..16]italic_u âˆˆ [ 4..16 ], and vâˆˆ[1..16]ğ‘£delimited-[]1..16v\in[1..16]italic_v âˆˆ [ 1..16 ], then by application of the MULTIPLICATION 3 rule to uâ‹…v=tâ‹…ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘¡u\cdot v=titalic_u â‹… italic_v = italic_t we reduce the domain of vğ‘£vitalic_v to [2..6]delimited-[]2..6[2..6][ 2..6 ]. Next, by application of the MULTIPLICATION 2 rule to the same constraint we reduce the domain of uğ‘¢uitalic_u to [4..12]delimited-[]4..12[4..12][ 4..12 ], and finally by application of the MULTIPLICATION 3 rule to wâ‹…x=uâ‹…ğ‘¤ğ‘¥ğ‘¢w\cdot x=uitalic_w â‹… italic_x = italic_u we reduce the domain of xğ‘¥xitalic_x from [1..4]delimited-[]1..4[1..4][ 1..4 ] to [1..3]delimited-[]1..3[1..3][ 1..3 ]. Note, however, that this effect depends on the decomposition. If we had decomposed the constraint as

zâ‹…(yâ‹…(xâ‹…w))=24â‹…ğ‘§â‹…ğ‘¦â‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¤24z\cdot(y\cdot(x\cdot w))=24italic_z â‹… ( italic_y â‹… ( italic_x â‹… italic_w ) ) = 24

with an auxiliary variable introduced for each pair of matching brackets, then we would not have been able to reduce any of the domains of xğ‘¥xitalic_x, yğ‘¦yitalic_y, and zğ‘§zitalic_z.

In the remainder of the paper we will also consider variants of the full decomposition approach where we allow squaring and exponentiation as atomic constraints. For this purpose we explain the reasoning for the constraint x=ynğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›x=y^{n}italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the presence of the non-empty ranges xâˆˆDxğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥x\in D_{x}italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and yâˆˆDyğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦y\in D_{y}italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and for n>1ğ‘›1n>1italic_n > 1. To this end we introduce the following two rules:

EXPONENTIATION

âŸ¨x=yn;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDyâŸ©âŸ¨x=yn;xâˆˆDxâ€²,yâˆˆDyâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥â€²ğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦\frac{\langle x=y^{n}\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}\rangle}{\langle x=y^{n}\ ;\ x\in D_{x}^{\prime},y\in D_{y}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

ROOT EXTRACTION

âŸ¨x=yn;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDyâŸ©âŸ¨x=yn;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDyâ€²âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦â€²\frac{\langle x=y^{n}\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}\rangle}{\langle x=y^{n}\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}^{\prime}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

where Dxâ€²:=Dxâˆ©intâ¡(Dyn)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥â€²subscriptğ·ğ‘¥intsubscriptsuperscriptğ·ğ‘›ğ‘¦D_{x}^{\prime}:=D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D^{n}_{y})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and Dyâ€²:=intâ¡(Dyâˆ©Dxn)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦â€²intsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘¥D_{y}^{\prime}:=\operatorname{int}(D_{y}\cap\sqrt[n]{D_{x}})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ).

To prove that these rules are equivalence preserving suppose that for some aâˆˆDxğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘¥a\in D_{x}italic_a âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bâˆˆDyğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘¦b\in D_{y}italic_b âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have a=bnğ‘superscriptğ‘ğ‘›a=b^{n}italic_a = italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then aâˆˆDynğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘›a\in D_{y}^{n}italic_a âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, so aâˆˆintâ¡(Dyn)ğ‘intsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘›a\in\operatorname{int}(D_{y}^{n})italic_a âˆˆ roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and consequently aâˆˆDxâˆ©intâ¡(Dyn)ğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘¥intsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘›a\in D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{y}^{n})italic_a âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Also bâˆˆDxnğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘¥b\in\sqrt[n]{D_{x}}italic_b âˆˆ nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, so bâˆˆDyâˆ©Dxnğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘¥b\in D_{y}\cap\sqrt[n]{D_{x}}italic_b âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, and consequently bâˆˆintâ¡(Dyâˆ©Dxn)ğ‘intsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘¥b\in\operatorname{int}(D_{y}\cap\sqrt[n]{D_{x}})italic_b âˆˆ roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ).

With exponentiation as an atomic constraint, full decomposition leads to idempotent rules, and the discussion at the end of SectionÂ 6 applies.

8 Relation to Hull and Box Consistency

In this section we relate the three approaches introduced above to the well-known methods for constraint propagation of arithmetic constraints on real variables, whose domains are represented by floating-point intervals. An overview of these methods is provided in [9]. Floating-point intervals are intervals of reals, with bounds from a finite set â„±âŠ†â„›âˆª{âˆ’âˆ,âˆ}â„±â„›\mathcal{F}\subseteq\mathcal{R}\cup\{-\infty,\infty\}caligraphic_F âŠ† caligraphic_R âˆª { - âˆ , âˆ } of floating-point numbers that contains representations âˆ’âˆ-\infty- âˆ and âˆ\inftyâˆ for plus and minus infinity. For floating-point intervals, the counterpart of the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) operation is the hull of a set of real numbers defined as the smallest floating-point interval containing the set. Ideally, for an arithmetic constraint cğ‘citalic_c on the variables x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},x_{n}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respective floating-point interval domains D1,â€¦,Dnsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{1},\mbox{$\ldots$},D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we would like to enforce hull consistency, which entails that for all iâˆˆ[1..n]i\in[1..n]italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ]

Di=hull(xiâˆˆâ„›âˆ£âˆƒx1âˆˆD1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1âˆˆDiâˆ’1,xi+1âˆˆDi+1,â€¦,xnâˆˆDn(x1,â€¦,xn)âˆˆC).\begin{array}[]{l@{\ }l}D_{i}=\operatorname{hull}(x_{i}\in\mathcal{R}\mid&\exists x_{1}\in D_{1},\ldots,x_{i-1}\in D_{i-1},x_{i+1}\in D_{i+1},\ldots,x_{n}\in D_{n}\\ &(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})\in C).\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_hull ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_R âˆ£ end_CELL start_CELL âˆƒ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ italic_C ) . end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

However, no efficient procedure exists for enforcing hull consistency on arbitrary arithmetic constraints. Therefore, the natural approach is to first decompose constraints into atomic constraints, each containing a single arithmetic operation. Maintaining hull consistency for the decomposed constraints can be done efficiently, using proof rules similar to the ones that we introduced, but hull consistency for the resulting decomposed CSP is a weaker notion of consistency than hull consistency for the original CSP.

Our full decomposition approach can be seen as the integer interval equivalent of the method for computing hull consistency for a decomposition that we just described, with the exception that linear constraints are not decomposed further. In the floating-point case, because of the accumulation of the rounding errors, the characterization of the resulting form of constraint propagation in terms of hull consistency is possible only if all constraints, including linear constraints, are decomposed into single-operator constraints.

To illustrate this consider the constraint x+y+z=wğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¤x+y+z=witalic_x + italic_y + italic_z = italic_w with the variables ranging over the floating-point intervals Dx,Dy,Dzsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘§D_{x},D_{y},D_{z}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Dwsubscriptğ·ğ‘¤D_{w}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. When we evaluate Dx+Dy+Dzsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘§D_{x}+D_{y}+D_{z}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the floating-point interval arithmetic to compute an update for Dwsubscriptğ·ğ‘¤D_{w}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have three options which two intervals to add first. Because the floating-point addition is non-associative, we actually compute the hull of a decomposition that has an extra variable added for either x+yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x+yitalic_x + italic_y, x+zğ‘¥ğ‘§x+zitalic_x + italic_z or y+zğ‘¦ğ‘§y+zitalic_y + italic_z, and the resulting interval is potentially a proper superset of hullâ¡(Dx+Dy+Dz)hullsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘§\operatorname{hull}(D_{x}+D_{y}+D_{z})roman_hull ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Moreover, different rewritings of the constraint correspond to different decompositions, and although this need not be a problem in practice, the resulting form of local consistency is no longer clearly defined.

In contrast, for integer intervals, we do not need to deal with the accumulation of the rounding errors and the linear constraints can be left intact. Our other two approaches can be seen as variants of the full decomposition approach that exploit this property further: for partial decomposition we allow more than one multiplication per proof rule, and in the direct approach the decomposition is not made explicit at all. Apart from these variations, all three approaches are the same in one important aspect: multiple occurrences of the same variable are treated as different variables. To illustrate this, consider the constraint x3+x=0superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¥0x^{3}+x=0italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x = 0, with xâˆˆ[âˆ’1..1]ğ‘¥delimited-[]1..1x\in[-1..1]italic_x âˆˆ [ - 1..1 ]. While x=0ğ‘¥0x=0italic_x = 0 is the unique solution, none of our three approaches will be able to reduce the domain of xğ‘¥xitalic_x. The reason is that the two occurrences of xğ‘¥xitalic_x are essentially treated as different variables in the reduction rules. This problem is known as the dependency problem of interval arithmetic.

In the context of constraints on reals [5] proposed to deal with the dependency problem using the notion of box consistency. It is a weaker notion of local consistency than hull consistency, but is potentially stronger than hull consistency for the decomposition of a constraint into atomic constraints (see, e.g., [9]). Enforcing box consistency, as described in [21], consists of fixing the domains of all variables except one, and then narrowing the domain of this variable by iteratively instantiating it with subdomains at the boundary of the original domain, each time verifying consistency of the constraint in the presence of the domains of the other variables, and subtracting the subdomain from the original domain if the instantiation leads to a failure.

The second step of the â€˜trial-and-pruneâ€™ procedure for enforcing box consistency that we just sketched can be implemented by enforcing hull consistency on a decomposition of the original constraint. So the procedure for enforcing box consistency can be seen as consisting of a number of procedures including the one that enforces hull consistency. One could apply the same technique to the arithmetic constraints on integer intervals, replacing the enforcement of hull consistency by one of our approaches to constraint propagation. This would lead to an integer equivalent of the box consistency. The efficiency of the resulting procedure depends on the choice of the underlying approach to constraint propagation, which provides another argument for the efficiency analysis of the approaches here considered.

9 A Characterization of the MULTIPLICATION Rules

It is useful to reflect on the effect of the proof rules used to achieve constraint propagation. In this section, by way of example, we focus on the MULTIPLICATION rules and characterize their effect using the notion of bounds consistency as defined in [16], limited to integer intervals. Let us recall first the definition that we adopt here to the multiplication constraint. Given an integer interval [l..h][l..h][ italic_l . . italic_h ] we denote by [l,h]ğ‘™â„[l,h][ italic_l , italic_h ] the corresponding real interval.

Definition 9.1

The CSP âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆ[lx..hx],yâˆˆ[ly..hy],zâˆˆ[lz..hz]âŸ©\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[l_{x}..h_{x}],y\in[l_{y}..h_{y}],z\in[l_{z}..h_{z}]\rangleâŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . . italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , italic_y âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . . italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , italic_z âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . . italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] âŸ© is called bounds consistent if

  • â€¢

    âˆ€aâˆˆ{lx,hx}â¢âˆƒbâˆˆ[ly,hy]â¢âˆƒcâˆˆ[lz,hz]â¢aâ‹…b=cfor-allğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¦subscriptâ„ğ‘¦ğ‘â‹…subscriptğ‘™ğ‘§subscriptâ„ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{$\forall$}a\in\mbox{$\{{l_{x},h_{x}}\}$}\ \mbox{$\exists$}b\in[l_{y},h_{y}]\ \mbox{$\exists$}c\in[l_{z},h_{z}]\ a\cdot b=câˆ€ italic_a âˆˆ { italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } âˆƒ italic_b âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] âˆƒ italic_c âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_a â‹… italic_b = italic_c,

  • â€¢

    âˆ€bâˆˆ{ly,hy}â¢âˆƒaâˆˆ[lx,hx]â¢âˆƒcâˆˆ[lz,hz]â¢aâ‹…b=cfor-allğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¦subscriptâ„ğ‘¦ğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘¥ğ‘â‹…subscriptğ‘™ğ‘§subscriptâ„ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{$\forall$}b\in\mbox{$\{{l_{y},h_{y}}\}$}\ \mbox{$\exists$}a\in[l_{x},h_{x}]\ \mbox{$\exists$}c\in[l_{z},h_{z}]\ a\cdot b=câˆ€ italic_b âˆˆ { italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } âˆƒ italic_a âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] âˆƒ italic_c âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_a â‹… italic_b = italic_c,

  • â€¢

    âˆ€câˆˆ{lz,hz}â¢âˆƒaâˆˆ[lx,hx]â¢âˆƒbâˆˆ[ly,hy]â¢aâ‹…b=cfor-allğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘§subscriptâ„ğ‘§ğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘¥ğ‘â‹…subscriptğ‘™ğ‘¦subscriptâ„ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\mbox{$\forall$}c\in\mbox{$\{{l_{z},h_{z}}\}$}\ \mbox{$\exists$}a\in[l_{x},h_{x}]\ \mbox{$\exists$}b\in[l_{y},h_{y}]\ a\cdot b=câˆ€ italic_c âˆˆ { italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } âˆƒ italic_a âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] âˆƒ italic_b âˆˆ [ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_a â‹… italic_b = italic_c. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

The following result entails that the MULTIPLICATION rules will not reduce a CSP beyond bounds consistency.

Theorem 9.2 (Bounds consistency)

Suppose a CSP âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencenormal-â‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© with the integer interval domains is bounds consistent. Then it is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1,2 and 3 rules.

Proof.Â See the Appendix. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

This theorem shows that the MULTIPLICATION rules entail a notion of local consistency, say Mğ‘€Mitalic_M-consistency, that is implied by bounds consistency. However, Mğ‘€Mitalic_M-consistency does not imply bounds consistency. Here is an example. Consider the CSP

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆ[âˆ’2..1],yâˆˆ[âˆ’3..10],zâˆˆ[8..10]âŸ©.delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥delimited-[]2..1formulae-sequenceğ‘¦delimited-[]3..10ğ‘§delimited-[]8..10\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[-2..1],y\in[-3..10],z\in[8..10]\rangle.âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ [ - 2..1 ] , italic_y âˆˆ [ - 3..10 ] , italic_z âˆˆ [ 8..10 ] âŸ© .

It is not bounds consistent, since for y=âˆ’3ğ‘¦3y=-3italic_y = - 3 no real values aâˆˆ[âˆ’2,1]ğ‘21a\in[-2,1]italic_a âˆˆ [ - 2 , 1 ] and câˆˆ[8,10]ğ‘810c\in[8,10]italic_c âˆˆ [ 8 , 10 ] exist such that aâ‹…(âˆ’3)=câ‹…ğ‘3ğ‘a\cdot(-3)=citalic_a â‹… ( - 3 ) = italic_c. Indeed, it is easy to check that

{yâˆˆâ„›âˆ£âˆƒxâˆˆ[âˆ’2,1]â¢âˆƒzâˆˆ[8,10]â¢xâ‹…y=z}=(âˆ’âˆ,âˆ’4]âˆª[8,âˆ).conditional-setğ‘¦â„›ğ‘¥21ğ‘§â‹…810ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§48\mbox{$\{{y\in{\cal R}\mid\mbox{$\exists$}x\in[-2,1]\>\mbox{$\exists$}z\in[8,10]\>x\cdot y=z}\}$}=(-\infty,-4]\cup[8,\infty).{ italic_y âˆˆ caligraphic_R âˆ£ âˆƒ italic_x âˆˆ [ - 2 , 1 ] âˆƒ italic_z âˆˆ [ 8 , 10 ] italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z } = ( - âˆ , - 4 ] âˆª [ 8 , âˆ ) .

However, this CSP is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1, 2 and 3 rules since

  • â€¢

    [8..10]âŠ†intâ¡([âˆ’2..1]â‹…[âˆ’3..10])delimited-[]8..10intâ‹…delimited-[]2..1delimited-[]3..10[8..10]\mbox{$\>\subseteq\>$}\operatorname{int}([-2..1]\cdot[-3..10])[ 8..10 ] âŠ† roman_int ( [ - 2..1 ] â‹… [ - 3..10 ] ), as intâ¡([âˆ’2..1]â‹…[âˆ’3..10])=[âˆ’20..10]intâ‹…delimited-[]2..1delimited-[]3..10delimited-[]20..10\operatorname{int}([-2..1]\cdot[-3..10])=[-20..10]roman_int ( [ - 2..1 ] â‹… [ - 3..10 ] ) = [ - 20..10 ],

  • â€¢

    [âˆ’2..1]âŠ†intâ¡([8..10]/[âˆ’3..10])delimited-[]2..1intdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]3..10[-2..1]\mbox{$\>\subseteq\>$}\operatorname{int}([8..10]/[-3..10])[ - 2..1 ] âŠ† roman_int ( [ 8..10 ] / [ - 3..10 ] ) as intâ¡([8..10]/[âˆ’3..10])=[âˆ’10..10]intdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]3..10delimited-[]10..10\operatorname{int}([8..10]/[-3..10])=[-10..10]roman_int ( [ 8..10 ] / [ - 3..10 ] ) = [ - 10..10 ], and

  • â€¢

    [âˆ’3..10]âŠ†intâ¡([8..10]/[âˆ’2..1])delimited-[]3..10intdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]2..1[-3..10]\mbox{$\>\subseteq\>$}\operatorname{int}([8..10]/[-2..1])[ - 3..10 ] âŠ† roman_int ( [ 8..10 ] / [ - 2..1 ] ) as intâ¡([8..10]/[âˆ’2..1])=[âˆ’10..10]intdelimited-[]8..10delimited-[]2..1delimited-[]10..10\operatorname{int}([8..10]/[-2..1])=[-10..10]roman_int ( [ 8..10 ] / [ - 2..1 ] ) = [ - 10..10 ].

The following result clarifies that this example identifies the only cause of discrepancy between Mğ‘€Mitalic_M-consistency and bounds consistency. Here, given an integer interval D:=[l..h]D:=[l..h]italic_D := [ italic_l . . italic_h ] we define âŸ¨DâŸ©:={xâˆˆğ’µâˆ£l<x<h}assigndelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ·conditional-setğ‘¥ğ’µğ‘™ğ‘¥â„\langle D\rangle:=\mbox{$\{{x\in{\cal Z}\mid l<x<h}\}$}âŸ¨ italic_D âŸ© := { italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_Z âˆ£ italic_l < italic_x < italic_h }.

Theorem 9.3 (Bounds consistency 2)

Consider a CSP Ï•:=âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©assignitalic-Ï•delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencenormal-â‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§\phi:=\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangleitalic_Ï• := âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© with non-empty integer interval domains and such that

0âˆˆâŸ¨DxâŸ©âˆ©âŸ¨DyâŸ©Â impliesÂ 0âˆˆDz.0âˆˆâŸ¨DxâŸ©âˆ©âŸ¨DyâŸ©Â impliesÂ 0âˆˆDz\mbox{$0\in\langle D_{x}\rangle\cap\langle D_{y}\rangle$ implies $0\in D_{z}$}.0 âˆˆ âŸ¨ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âˆ© âŸ¨ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© implies 0 âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (5)

Suppose Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1,2 and 3 rules. Then it is bounds consistent.

Proof.Â See the Appendix. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Consequently the MULTIPLICATION rules only fail to enforce bounds consistency for the constraint xâ‹…y=zâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§x\cdot y=zitalic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z in case the domains of xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y are both of the form [l..h][l..h][ italic_l . . italic_h ], with l<0ğ‘™0l<0italic_l < 0 and h>0â„0h>0italic_h > 0 while zğ‘§zitalic_z can assume either only positive numbers, or only negative numbers. Because the zeroes in the domains of xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y do not contribute to any solution, we can remedy this effect by temporarily splitting these domains in a positive interval and a negative interval. Bounds consistency for the constraint xâ‹…y=zâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§x\cdot y=zitalic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z is then achieved by applying the MULTIPLICATION rules to the resulting subproblems, and updating the domain of each variable with the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) closure of the union of its domain in these subproblems.

In [20] similar rules to our MULTIPLICATION rules are defined that apply this technique directly. They were defined without the use of interval arithmetic. It is also shown there that the LINEAR EQUALITY and LINEAR INEQUALITY rules enforce bounds consistency.

10 Implementation Details

10.1 Weak Division

We already mentioned in Section 3 that the division operation on the intervals does not admit an efficient implementation. The reason is that the intâ¡(â‹…)intâ‹…\operatorname{int}(\cdot)roman_int ( â‹… ) closure of the interval division [a..b]/[c..d][a..b]/[c..d][ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] requires an auxiliary computation in case when 0âˆ‰[c..d]0\not\in[c..d]0 âˆ‰ [ italic_c . . italic_d ]. The preprocessing of [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ] becomes impractical for small intervals [a..b][a..b][ italic_a . . italic_b ], and large [c..d][c..d][ italic_c . . italic_d ], occurring for example for the constraint âˆi=1nxi=âˆi=1nisuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘–\prod_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}iâˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i, of the benchmark problem mentioned in SubsectionÂ 1.1. This can be remedied by using the following variant of the division operation. We call it weak division since it yields a larger set (and so is â€˜weakerâ€™).

[a..b]:[c..d]:={[âŒˆmin(A)âŒ‰..âŒŠmax(A)âŒ‹]ifÂ 0âˆ‰[c..d], orifÂ 0âˆ‰[a..b]Â andÂ 0âˆˆ{c,d}Â andÂ c<d,[a..b]/[c..d]otherwise[a..b]:[c..d]:=\left\{\begin{tabular}[]{ll}$[\left\lceil\operatorname{min}(A)\right\rceil..\left\lfloor\operatorname{max}(A)\right\rfloor]$&\mbox{if $0\not\in[c..d]$, or}\\ &\mbox{\phantom{if} $0\notin[a..b]$} and $0\in\{c,d\}$ and $c<d$,\\ $[a..b]/[c..d]$&otherwise\end{tabular}\right.[ italic_a . . italic_b ] : [ italic_c . . italic_d ] := { start_ROW start_CELL [ âŒˆ roman_min ( italic_A ) âŒ‰ . . âŒŠ roman_max ( italic_A ) âŒ‹ ] end_CELL start_CELL if 0âˆ‰[c..d], or end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL if 0âˆ‰[a..b] and 0 âˆˆ { italic_c , italic_d } and italic_c < italic_d , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW

where A={a/câ€²,a/dâ€²,b/câ€²,b/dâ€²}ğ´ğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘‘â€²A=\mbox{$\{{a/c^{\prime},a/d^{\prime},b/c^{\prime},b/d^{\prime}}\}$}italic_A = { italic_a / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a / italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b / italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b / italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, and [câ€²..dâ€²]=[c..d]âˆ’{0}[c^{\prime}..d^{\prime}]=[c..d]-\{0\}[ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . . italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = [ italic_c . . italic_d ] - { 0 }.

Then int([a..b]:[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]:[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] : [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) can be computed by a straightforward case analysis already used for int([a..b]/[c..d])\operatorname{int}([a..b]/[c..d])roman_int ( [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ] ) but now without any auxiliary computation. The weak division operator gives rise to the following versions of the MULTIPLICATION rules 2 and 3:

MULTIPLICATION 2w

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDxâ€²,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥â€²formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x}^{\prime},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

MULTIPLICATION 3w

âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDyâ€²,zâˆˆDzâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦â€²ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§\frac{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangle}{\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y}^{\prime},z\in D_{z}\rangle}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG

where Dxâ€²:=Dxâˆ©intâ¡(Dz:Dy)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥â€²subscriptğ·ğ‘¥int:subscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¦D_{x}^{\prime}:=D_{x}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}:D_{y})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and Dyâ€²:=Dyâˆ©intâ¡(Dz:Dx)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¦â€²subscriptğ·ğ‘¦int:subscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¥D_{y}^{\prime}:=D_{y}\cap\operatorname{int}(D_{z}:D_{x})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ© roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

In the assumed framework based on constraint propagation and tree search, all domains become eventually singletons or empty sets. It can easily be verified that both division operations are then equal, i.e., [a..b]:[c..d]=[a..b]/[c..d][a..b]:[c..d]=[a..b]/[c..d][ italic_a . . italic_b ] : [ italic_c . . italic_d ] = [ italic_a . . italic_b ] / [ italic_c . . italic_d ], for aâ‰¥bğ‘ğ‘a\geq bitalic_a â‰¥ italic_b and câ‰¥dğ‘ğ‘‘c\geq ditalic_c â‰¥ italic_d. For this reason, we can safely replace any of the reduction rules introduced in this paper, notably POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY, POLYNOMIAL INEQUALITY, and MULTIPLICATION 2 and 3, by their counterparts based on the weak division. For the MULTIPLICATION rules specifically, the following theorem states that both sets of rules actually achieve the same constraint propagation.

Theorem 10.1 (MULTIPLICATION)

A CSP âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencenormal-â‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© with the integer interval domains is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1, 2 and 3 rules iff it is closed under the applications of the MULTIPLICATION 1, 2w and 3w rules.

Proof.Â See the Appendix. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡


Let us clarify now the relation between the MULTIPLICATION rules and the corresponding rules based on real interval arithmetic combined with the rounding of the resulting real intervals inwards to the largest integer intervals. The CSP âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆ[âˆ’3..3],yâˆˆ[âˆ’1..1],zâˆˆ[1..2]âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥delimited-[]3..3formulae-sequenceğ‘¦delimited-[]1..1ğ‘§delimited-[]1..2\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in[-3..3],y\in[-1..1],z\in[1..2]\rangleâŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ [ - 3..3 ] , italic_y âˆˆ [ - 1..1 ] , italic_z âˆˆ [ 1..2 ] âŸ©, which we already discussed in the introduction, shows that these approaches yield different results. Indeed, using the MULTIPLICATION rule 2 we can reduce the domain of xğ‘¥xitalic_x to [âˆ’2..2]delimited-[]2..2[-2..2][ - 2..2 ], while the latter approach yields no reduction.

On the other hand, the applications of the MULTIPLICATION rules 2w and 3w to âŸ¨xâ‹…y=z;xâˆˆDx,yâˆˆDy,zâˆˆDzâŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequenceâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§formulae-sequenceğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¦subscriptğ·ğ‘¦ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘§\langle x\cdot y=z\ ;\ x\in D_{x},y\in D_{y},z\in D_{z}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_x â‹… italic_y = italic_z ; italic_x âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© such that intâ¡(Dz:Dx)â‰ intâ¡(Dz/Dx)int:subscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¥intsubscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¥\operatorname{int}(D_{z}:D_{x})\neq\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{x})roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰  roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and intâ¡(Dz:Dy)â‰ intâ¡(Dz/Dy)int:subscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¦intsubscriptğ·ğ‘§subscriptğ·ğ‘¦\operatorname{int}(D_{z}:D_{y})\neq\operatorname{int}(D_{z}/D_{y})roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰  roman_int ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (so in cases when the use of the weak interval division differs from the use of the interval division) do coincide with the just discussed approach based on real interval arithmetic and inward rounding. This is a consequence of the way the multiplication and division of real intervals are defined, see [15]. However, as we already stated in the introduction, we believe that the limited precision of floating-point interval arithmetic, and the modest overhead of arbitrary length integers justify a separate implementation of these rules for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals.

10.2 Implementation

Platform

Our experiments were performed using OpenSolverÂ [23], an experimental constraint solver based on constraint propagation and tree search. OpenSolver can be configured by software plug-ins in a number of predefined categories, corresponding to different aspects of constraint propagation and tree search, which makes it particularly well-suited for carrying out comparative studies of implementations of constraint solvers. The categories of plug-ins that are relevant for the experiments reported here are:

  • â€¢

    variable domain types, which implement the domains of variables,

  • â€¢

    domain reduction functions (DRFs), which correspond to the reduction rules,

  • â€¢

    schedulers of DRFs, which determine the order in which the DRFs are applied,

  • â€¢

    branching strategies, which split the search tree after constraint propagation has terminated, and

  • â€¢

    several categories corresponding to different aspects of a search strategy that determine how to traverse a search tree.

All experiments were performed using the IntegerInterval variable domain type plug-in. Domains of this type consist of an indication of the type of the interval (bounded, unbounded, left/right-bounded, or empty), and a pair of arbitrary length integer bounds. This plug-in, and the DRFs operating on it are built using the already mentioned GNU MP library, which provides arbitrary length integers and arithmetic operations on them, including operations for rounding the outcome of divisions and root extractions in the desired direction.

The branching strategy that we used selects variables using a chronological ordering in which the auxiliary variables come last. The domain of the selected variable is split into two subdomains using bisection, so the resulting search trees are binary trees. In all experiments we searched for all solutions, traversing the entire search tree by means of depth-first leftmost-first chronological backtracking.

For the experiments in this paper a DRF plug-in has been developed that implements the domain reduction rules discussed in the previous sections. Every constraint of a CSP is enforced by a number of instantiations of this DRF: one for each variable occurrence.

The scheduler plug-in that we used in the experiments maintains a flag per DRF, indicating whether the DRF is pending application or not. Initially, all DRFs are pending application. If the application of a DRF (or the branching strategy) modifies the domains of one or more variables, all DRFs whose output depends on these variables become pending application. Since in general â€”as illustrated by the example at the beginning of SectionÂ 5â€” the DRFs are non-idempotent, this may include the DRF that has just been applied. By default, the scheduler plug-in keeps cycling through the set of DRFs for a given CSP in a specified order, applying those DRFs that are pending application. The cycling stops when no DRF is pending application, or when the domain of a variable becomes empty.

Scheduling of Reduction Rules

It was already shown in [22] that controlling the order in which variables are updated can improve the efficiency of constraint propagation algorithms, and for this purpose, our scheduler plug-in can be supplied with a schedule. Such a schedule is a sequence of indices into the set of DRFs that describes the order in which the scheduler will visit them, as an alternative to cycling. This is used in combination with full and partial decomposition, where we distinguish user constraints from the constraints that are introduced to define the values of auxiliary variables. Before considering for execution a DRF fğ‘“fitalic_f that is part of the implementation of a user constraint, we make sure that all auxiliary variables that fğ‘“fitalic_f relies on are updated. For this purpose, the indices of the DRFs that update these variables precede the index of fğ‘“fitalic_f in the schedule. If fğ‘“fitalic_f can change the value of an auxiliary variable, its index is followed by the indices of the DRFs that propagate back these changes to the variables that define the value of this auxiliary variable.

For example, rewriting x3â‹…yâˆ’xâ‰¤40â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦ğ‘¥40x^{3}\cdot y-x\leq 40italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y - italic_x â‰¤ 40 to simple constraints introduces an auxiliary variable uğ‘¢uitalic_u, which is equated with x3â‹…yâ‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦x^{3}\cdot yitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y. This leads to five reduction rules: one for each occurrence of a variable after the rewriting step. We number these reduction rules as follows, where we underline in the constraint the variable that is updated by the rule:


1. uÂ¯=x3â‹…yÂ¯ğ‘¢â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦\underline{u}=x^{3}\cdot yunderÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y 2. u=xÂ¯3â‹…yğ‘¢â‹…superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥3ğ‘¦u=\underline{x}^{3}\cdot yitalic_u = underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y 3. u=x3â‹…yÂ¯ğ‘¢â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3Â¯ğ‘¦u=x^{3}\cdot\underline{y}italic_u = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG

4. uÂ¯âˆ’xâ‰¤40Â¯ğ‘¢ğ‘¥40\underline{u}-x\leq 40underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG - italic_x â‰¤ 40 5. uâˆ’xÂ¯â‰¤40ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘¥40u-\underline{x}\leq 40italic_u - underÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG â‰¤ 40


The fragment of the generated schedule that corresponds to enforcing the constraint x3â‹…yâˆ’xâ‰¤40â‹…superscriptğ‘¥3ğ‘¦ğ‘¥40x^{3}\cdot y-x\leq 40italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y - italic_x â‰¤ 40 is then 4,2,3,1,5. Rules 4 and 5 correspond to the original inequality, but rule 4 potentially modifies uğ‘¢uitalic_u, so in the schedule, rule 4 is followed by rules 2 and 3, that propagate any changes to uğ‘¢uitalic_u back to xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y. Before considering rule 5 for application, the schedule specifies that first rule 1 should be considered, so that any changes to the domains of xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y are propagated to the domain of uğ‘¢uitalic_u.

To see that an appropriate scheduling of the rules can be beneficial compared to cycling through the rules, suppose that all rules are pending application, and that Dx=Dy=[1..100]subscriptğ·ğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘¦delimited-[]1..100D_{x}=D_{y}=[1..100]italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ 1..100 ], and Dz=ğ’µsubscriptğ·ğ‘§ğ’µD_{z}=\mathcal{Z}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_Z. If we iterate the rules in their original order 1,2,3,4,5 then we first reduce Dusubscriptğ·ğ‘¢D_{u}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to [1..1004]delimited-[]superscript1..1004[1..100^{4}][ 1..100 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] by means of rule 1. Next, rules 2 and 3 are executed without making any changes. Rule 4 then reduces Dusubscriptğ·ğ‘¢D_{u}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to [1..140]delimited-[]1..140[1..140][ 1..140 ], which makes rules 2 and 3 pending application again. Next, rule 5555 is executed without reducing Dxsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥D_{x}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Because xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y have not changed, rule 1 is not set to pending application, and rule 2 is the first rule that is applied in the second cycle, which reduces Dxsubscriptğ·ğ‘¥D_{x}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to [1..5]delimited-[]1..5[1..5][ 1..5 ]. If use the generated schedule 4,2,3,1,5 instead, the same reduction is achieved immediately after applying the first two rules, instead of the six rules that are applied if we just cycle through the rules.

For full decomposition, there can be hierarchical dependencies between auxiliary variables. Much like the HC4revise procedure ofÂ [4], the generated schedule then specifies a bottom-up traversal of this hierarchy in a forward evaluation phase, and a top-down traversal in a backward propagation phase. These phases are performed before and after applying a DRF of a user constraint, respectively. In the forward evaluation phase, the DRFs that are executed correspond to the MULTIPLICATION 1 and EXPONENTIATION rules. The DRFs of the backward propagation phase correspond to the MULTIPLICATION 2 and 3, and ROOT EXTRACTION rules. The HC4revise procedure is part of the HC4 algorithm, which enforces hull consistency for constraints on the reals using an implicit decomposition. For a discussion of this algorithm in the context of controlled constraint propagation, see [12].

Constraint Rewriting

The proposed approaches were implemented by first rewriting arithmetic constraints to polynomial constraints, and then to a sequence of DRFs that correspond to the rules of the approach used. We implemented the following variants:

  • ğğ®subscriptğğ®\mathbf{d_{u}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
