    (direct, unoptimized): the direct approach, discussed in Section 5, where we isolate all variable occurrences in the original constraints without decomposing them first;

  • ğğ¨subscriptğğ¨\mathbf{d_{o}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

    (direct, optimized): the optimization of the direct approach, discussed at the end of Section 5, which involves dividing out common powers of variables in the extended arithmetic expressions that arise from isolating the variable occurrences;

  • ğ©ğ®subscriptğ©ğ®\mathbf{p_{u}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

    (partial, unoptimized): partial decomposition into simple constraints, as discussed in Section 6. The decomposition is implemented by introducing an auxiliary variable for every nonlinear power product. This procedure may introduce more auxiliary variables than necessary;

  • ğ©ğ¨subscriptğ©ğ¨\mathbf{p_{o}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

    (partial, optimized): an optimized version of variant ğ©ğ®subscriptğ©ğ®\mathbf{p_{u}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where we stop introducing auxiliary variables as soon as the constraints contain no more duplicate occurrences of variables;

  • ğŸğ¦subscriptğŸğ¦\mathbf{f_{m}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

    (full, multiplication): full decomposition into atomic constraints, as discussed in Section 7, allowing only linear constraints and multiplication as atomic constraints;

  • ğŸğ¬subscriptğŸğ¬\mathbf{f_{s}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

    (full, squaring): idem, but also allowing x=y2ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦2x=y^{2}italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as an atomic constraint;

  • ğŸğsubscriptğŸğ\mathbf{f_{e}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

    (full, exponentiation): idem, allowing x=ynğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›x=y^{n}italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all n>1ğ‘›1n>1italic_n > 1 as an atomic constraint.

If the distinction between the different variants of an approach is irrelevant, we will sometimes omit the subscripts to the names ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d, ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}bold_p, and ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f}bold_f.

Full and partial decomposition are implemented as a rewrite step, where the auxiliary variables are introduced. The resulting CSP is then rewritten using the direct approach. During the first rewrite step the hierarchical relations between the auxiliary variables are recorded, and the schedules are generated as a part of the second rewrite step. For variants ğ©ğ¨subscriptğ©ğ¨\mathbf{p_{o}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f}bold_f the question of which auxiliary variables to introduce is an optimization problem in itself. Some choices result in more auxiliary variables than others. We have not treated this issue as an optimization problem but relied on the (somewhat arbitrary) heuristics described below. For this reason we have to consider the possibility that performance of variants ğ©ğ¨subscriptğ©ğ¨\mathbf{p_{o}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f}bold_f can be further improved because in our experiments we used a suboptimal decomposition. The heuristics are as follows.

  • â€¢

    For variant ğ©ğ¨subscriptğ©ğ¨\mathbf{p_{o}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we replace nonlinear power products from left to right, so the rightmost nonlinear term of a polynomial constraint is always left intact.

  • â€¢

    For the full decomposition approach, nonlinear power products are processed in the order in which they occur in the problem statement, after normalization to polynomial constraints. On the first occurrence of a nonlinear power product, we start introducing auxiliary variables for terms that divide the power product by multiplying or exponentiating existing variables, and keep doing so until we have introduced an auxiliary variable that corresponds to the full power product. When there are several choices for which existing variables to multiply or exponentiate, we introduce an auxiliary variable for a term with the largest possible sum of exponents, thereby giving preference to exponentiation over multiplication, insofar as it is allowed by the variant. For variant ğŸğsubscriptğŸğ\mathbf{f_{e}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we first introduce auxiliary variables for all exponentiations in the power product. For variant ğŸğ¬subscriptğŸğ¬\mathbf{f_{s}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we first introduce auxiliary variables for all exponentiations that divide the power product, and whose exponent is a power of 2. Unused auxiliary variables are deleted at a later stage.

To illustrate the latter heuristic, suppose we want to introduce an auxiliary variable for the term x5â‹…y3â‹…zâ‹…superscriptğ‘¥5superscriptğ‘¦3ğ‘§x^{5}\cdot y^{3}\cdot zitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z. If we allow exponentiation, we start by introducing auxiliary variables u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the exponentiations in the term, and constrain them as follows: u1=x5subscriptğ‘¢1superscriptğ‘¥5u_{1}=x^{5}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, u2=y3subscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘¦3u_{2}=y^{3}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Next we can introduce an auxiliary variable u3subscriptğ‘¢3u_{3}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for x5â‹…y3â‹…superscriptğ‘¥5superscriptğ‘¦3x^{5}\cdot y^{3}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, x5â‹…zâ‹…superscriptğ‘¥5ğ‘§x^{5}\cdot zitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z, or y3â‹…zâ‹…superscriptğ‘¦3ğ‘§y^{3}\cdot zitalic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_z by adding a constraint that multiplies two of the variables u1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, u2subscriptğ‘¢2u_{2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and zğ‘§zitalic_z. Because the sum of exponents is highest for the first option, we add u3=u1â‹…u2subscriptğ‘¢3â‹…subscriptğ‘¢1subscriptğ‘¢2u_{3}=u_{1}\cdot u_{2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Finally u4subscriptğ‘¢4u_{4}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is introduced to replace the original term: u4=u3â‹…zsubscriptğ‘¢4â‹…subscriptğ‘¢3ğ‘§u_{4}=u_{3}\cdot zitalic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_z. With only squaring allowed, we would be making these decisions in the presence of auxiliary variables for x2superscriptğ‘¥2x^{2}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, x4superscriptğ‘¥4x^{4}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and y2superscriptğ‘¦2y^{2}italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where x4superscriptğ‘¥4x^{4}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obtained by squaring x2superscriptğ‘¥2x^{2}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In this case, the first auxiliary variable introduced would be for x4â‹…y2â‹…superscriptğ‘¥4superscriptğ‘¦2x^{4}\cdot y^{2}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. With only multiplication allowed, after introducing u1=xâ‹…xsubscriptğ‘¢1â‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘¥u_{1}=x\cdot xitalic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x â‹… italic_x and u2=u1â‹…u1subscriptğ‘¢2â‹…subscriptğ‘¢1subscriptğ‘¢1u_{2}=u_{1}\cdot u_{1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we would be expanding the term be repeatedly multiplying it with xğ‘¥xitalic_x, yğ‘¦yitalic_y, or zğ‘§zitalic_z.

Except for the optimized version of the direct approach, our current implementation can be optimized further by adopting the two-step propagation of linear constraints described in [14], as discussed at the end of SectionÂ 4. Because linear constraints are never decomposed, the effect is essentially the same for all alternatives that we discussed, so we have not considered this technique in our evaluation.

11 Experiments

11.1 Problems

For evaluating the alternative approaches, we used the integer problems described below. Problems with only integer variables and arithmetic constraints are rare in practice, and in that sense, our benchmark problems are artificial, but they serve well to generate a purely integer workload. The approach that works best on these problems can also be expected to work well in a hybrid setting, where integer variables and arithmetic constraints are mixed with other types of variables and constraints. In that case, only a fraction of the workload will be devoted to integer arithmetic, but with the results of this study we can be confident that we are dealing with these constraints in an efficient way.

Cubes

The problem is to find all natural numbers nâ‰¤105ğ‘›superscript105n\leq 10^{5}italic_n â‰¤ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that are a sum of four different cubes, for example

13+23+33+43=100.superscript13superscript23superscript33superscript431001^{3}+2^{3}+3^{3}+4^{3}=100.1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 100 .

This problem is modeled as follows:

âŸ¨1â‰¤x1,x1â‰¤x2âˆ’1,x2â‰¤x3âˆ’1,x3â‰¤x4âˆ’1,x4â‰¤n,x13+x23+x33+x43=n;nâˆˆ[1..105],x1,x2,x3,x4âˆˆğ’µâŸ©\begin{array}[]{l}\langle 1\leq x_{1},\ x_{1}\leq x_{2}-1,\ x_{2}\leq x_{3}-1,\ x_{3}\leq x_{4}-1,\ x_{4}\leq n,\\ \phantom{\langle}x_{1}^{3}+x_{2}^{3}+x_{3}^{3}+x_{4}^{3}=n;\ n\in[1..10^{5}],\ x_{1},x_{2},x_{3},x_{4}\in{\cal Z}\rangle\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL âŸ¨ 1 â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_n , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_n ; italic_n âˆˆ [ 1..10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_Z âŸ© end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY
Opt

We are interested in finding a solution to the constraint x3+y2=z3superscriptğ‘¥3superscriptğ‘¦2superscriptğ‘§3x^{3}+y^{2}=z^{3}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the integer interval [1..105]delimited-[]superscript1..105[1..10^{5}][ 1..10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] for which the value of 2â¢xâ‹…yâˆ’zâ‹…2ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§2x\cdot y-z2 italic_x â‹… italic_y - italic_z is maximal.

Fractions

This problem is taken fromÂ [19]: find distinct nonzero digits such that the following equation holds:

ABâ¢C+DEâ¢F+GHâ¢I=1ğ´ğµğ¶ğ·ğ¸ğ¹ğºğ»ğ¼1\frac{A}{BC}+\frac{D}{EF}+\frac{G}{HI}=1divide start_ARG italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_B italic_C end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_ARG italic_E italic_F end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_G end_ARG start_ARG italic_H italic_I end_ARG = 1

There is a variable for each letter. The initial domains are [1..9]delimited-[]1..9[1..9][ 1..9 ]. To avoid symmetric solutions an ordering is imposed:

ABâ¢Câ‰¥DEâ¢Fâ‰¥GHâ¢Iğ´ğµğ¶ğ·ğ¸ğ¹ğºğ»ğ¼\frac{A}{BC}\geq\frac{D}{EF}\geq\frac{G}{HI}divide start_ARG italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_B italic_C end_ARG â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_ARG italic_E italic_F end_ARG â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_G end_ARG start_ARG italic_H italic_I end_ARG

Also two redundant constraints are added:

3â¢ABâ¢Câ‰¥1and3â¢GHâ¢Iâ‰¤1formulae-sequence3ğ´ğµğ¶1and3ğºğ»ğ¼13\frac{A}{BC}\geq 1\qquad\textrm{and}\qquad 3\frac{G}{HI}\leq 13 divide start_ARG italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_B italic_C end_ARG â‰¥ 1 and 3 divide start_ARG italic_G end_ARG start_ARG italic_H italic_I end_ARG â‰¤ 1

Because division is not present in our arithmetic expressions, the above constraints are multiplied by the denominators of the fractions to obtain arithmetic constraints. We studied a representation for this problem using one equality and four inequalities for the ordering and the redundant constraints, and 36 disequalities Aâ‰ Bğ´ğµA\neq Bitalic_A â‰  italic_B, Aâ‰ Cğ´ğ¶A\neq Citalic_A â‰  italic_C, â€¦, Hâ‰ Iğ»ğ¼H\neq Iitalic_H â‰  italic_I.

Kyoto

The problem (see [10]) is to find the number nğ‘›nitalic_n such that the alphanumeric equation

K Y O T O
K Y O T O
+ K Y O T O
T O K Y O

has a solution in the base-nğ‘›nitalic_n number system. Our representation uses a variable for each letter and one variable for the base number. The variables Kğ¾Kitalic_K and Tğ‘‡Titalic_T may not be zero. There is one large constraint for the addition, 6 disequalities Kâ‰ Yğ¾ğ‘ŒK\neq Yitalic_K â‰  italic_Y â€¦ Tâ‰ Oğ‘‡ğ‘‚T\neq Oitalic_T â‰  italic_O and four constraints stating that the individual digits K,Y,O,Tğ¾ğ‘Œğ‘‚ğ‘‡K,Y,O,Titalic_K , italic_Y , italic_O , italic_T, are smaller than the base number. To spend some CPU time, we searched base numbers 2..100.

Sumprod

This is the problem cited in SubsectionÂ 1.1, for n=14ğ‘›14n=14italic_n = 14. We use the following representation:

âŸ¨x1+â€¦+xn=c1+â€¦+cn,x1â‹…â€¦â‹…xn=c1â‹…â€¦â‹…cn,x1â‰¤x2,x2â‰¤x3,â€¦,xnâˆ’1â‰¤xn;x1,â€¦,xnâˆˆ[1..n],c1âˆˆ{1},c2âˆˆ{2},â€¦,cnâˆˆ{n}âŸ©\begin{array}[]{l}\langle x_{1}+\ldots+x_{n}=c_{1}+\ldots+c_{n},\\ \phantom{\langle}x_{1}\cdot\ldots\cdot x_{n}=c_{1}\cdot\ldots\cdot c_{n},\\ \phantom{\langle}x_{1}\leq x_{2},x_{2}\leq x_{3},\ldots,x_{n-1}\leq x_{n}\ ;\\ \phantom{\langle}x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in[1..n],\\ \phantom{\langle}c_{1}\in\{1\},c_{2}\in\{2\},\ldots,c_{n}\in\{n\}\rangle\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL âŸ¨ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + â€¦ + italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + â€¦ + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… â€¦ â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… â€¦ â‹… italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 1 . . italic_n ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 1 } , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 2 } , â€¦ , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { italic_n } âŸ© end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

For n=14ğ‘›14n=14italic_n = 14, the value of the expression âˆi=1nisuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘–\prod_{i=1}^{n}iâˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i equals 14!1414!14 !, which exceeds 232superscript2322^{32}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 32 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and to avoid problems with the input of large numbers, we used bound variables c1,â€¦,cnsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›c_{1},\ldots,c_{n}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and constraint propagation to evaluate it.

11.2 Results

TablesÂ 2 andÂ 3 compare the implemented variants of our approaches on the problems defined in the previous subsection. The first two columns of tableÂ 2 list the number of variables and DRFs that were used. Column nodes lists the size of the search tree, including failures and solutions. The next two columns list the number of times that a DRF was applied, and the percentage of these applications that the domain of a variable was actually modified. For the opt problem, the DRF that implements the optimization is not counted, and its application is not taken into account. The reported CPU times are user time in seconds, as reported by the UNIX time command on a 1200 MHz Athlon CPU. The last column compares the performance of our implementation to that of ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT, and will be discussed at the end of this section.

TableÂ 3 lists measured numbers of basic interval operations. Note that for variant ğğ¨subscriptğğ¨\mathbf{d_{o}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there are two versions of the division and addition operations: one for integer intervals, and one for intervals of reals of which the bounds are rational numbers (marked ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q). Columns multI and multF list the numbers of multiplications of two integer intervals, and of an integer interval and an integer factor, respectively. These are different operations in our implementation.

For the cubes, opt, and sumprod problems, the constraints are already in simple form, so variants ğğ®subscriptğğ®\mathbf{d_{u}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğğ¨subscriptğğ¨\mathbf{d_{o}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ©ğ¨subscriptğ©ğ¨\mathbf{p_{o}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are identical. For cubes and opt all nonlinear terms involve a single multiplication or exponentiation, so for these experiments also variants ğ©ğ®subscriptğ©ğ®\mathbf{p_{u}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğŸğsubscriptğŸğ\mathbf{f_{e}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the same. For the fractions problem, and for sumprod, no exponentiations are used, so all three variants of the full decomposition approach that we implemented are identical.

The results of these experiments clearly show the disadvantage of implementing exponentiation by means of multiplication: there is less domain reduction because we increase the number of variable occurrences (see the dependency problem, discussed in SectionÂ 8). For opt and variant ğŸğ¦subscriptğŸğ¦\mathbf{f_{m}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the run did not complete within reasonable time and was aborted.

For fractions the symbolic manipulation of variant ğğ¨subscriptğğ¨\mathbf{d_{o}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reduces the search tree by a factor 0.700.700.700.70. However, this reduction is not reflected in the timings, and in fact the CPU time even increases. The reason is that computing the domain updates involves adding intervals of real numbers. The arithmetic operations on such intervals are more expensive than their counterparts on integer intervals, because the bounds have to be maintained as rational numbers. Arithmetic operations on rational numbers are more expensive because they involve the computation of greatest common divisors. For kyoto the symbolic manipulation did not reduce the size of the search tree, so the effect is even more severe.

In general, the introduction of auxiliary variables leads to a reduction of the number of interval operations compared to the direct approach. As discussed at the end of SectionÂ 6, this is because auxiliary variables prevent the evaluation of subexpressions that did not change. This effect is strongest for fractions, where the main constraint contains a large number of different power products. Without auxiliary variables all power products are evaluated for every POLYNOMIAL EQUALITY rule defined by this constraint, even those power products the variable domains of which did not change. With auxiliary variables the intervals for such unmodified terms are available immediately, which leads to a significant reduction of the number of interval multiplications. For sumprod, the difference between variants ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d and ğ©ğ®subscriptğ©ğ®\mathbf{p_{u}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a bit artificial, because the operations that are saved involve the computation of the constant term c1â‹…â€¦â‹…cnâ‹…subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›c_{1}\cdot\ldots\cdot c_{n}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… â€¦ â‹… italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. AÂ comparable number of interval additions can be saved if we introduce a variable for the constant term c1+â€¦+cnsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›c_{1}+\ldots+c_{n}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + â€¦ + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If we add these variables to the CSP all variants of the direct and partial decomposition approaches are essentially the same.

That stronger reduction is achieved as a result of full decomposition, mentioned in SectionÂ 7, is seen for the fractions benchmark and more prominently for sumprod. In the latter benchmark, this effect depends on a decomposition of the term âˆi=1nxisuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\prod_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as x1â‹…(x2â‹…(â€¦â‹…(xnâˆ’1â‹…xn)â¢â€¦))â‹…subscriptğ‘¥1â‹…subscriptğ‘¥2â‹…â€¦â‹…subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›â€¦x_{1}\cdot(x_{2}\cdot(\ldots\cdot(x_{n-1}\cdot x_{n})\ldots))italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( â€¦ â‹… ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â€¦ ) ), with an auxiliary variable for each pair of matching brackets. The decomposition then matches the chronological ordering used to select the variable for branching. If the ordering is reversed, the number of nodes is equal to that of the other approaches. The effect described in SectionÂ 6 is not demonstrated by these experiments.

If we do not consider the symbolic manipulation of variant ğğ¨subscriptğğ¨\mathbf{d_{o}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, variant ğŸğsubscriptğŸğ\mathbf{f_{e}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT leads to the smallest total number of interval operations in all cases, but the scheduling mechanism discussed in SectionÂ 10 is essential for a consistent good performance. If for example the schedule is omitted for opt, the number of interval operations almost triples, and performance of variants ğ©ğ®subscriptğ©ğ®\mathbf{p_{u}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğŸğsubscriptğŸğ\mathbf{f_{e}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is then much worse than that of ğğ®subscriptğğ®\mathbf{d_{u}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is conform the observations of [12], where it is demonstrated that for constraints on reals, enforcing hull consistency for a decomposition through repeated application of the HC4revise procedure yields superior performance compared to the basic HC3 algorithm. Based on these observations, we expect that the benefit of using the schedule will grow with the number of variables.

The total numbers of interval operations in tableÂ 3 do not fully explain all differences in elapsed times. One of the reasons is that different interval operations have different costs. Also some overhead is involved in applying a reduction rule, so if the number of applications differs significantly for two experiments, this influences the elapsed times as well (opt, ğğ\mathbf{d}bold_d, ğ©ğ®subscriptğ©ğ®\mathbf{p_{u}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). The elapsed times are not the only measure that is subject to implementation details. For example, we implemented division by a constant interval [âˆ’1..âˆ’1][-1..-1][ - 1 . . - 1 ] as multiplication by a constant, which is more efficient in our implementation. Such decisions are reflected in the numbers reported in tableÂ 3.

For each of the benchmarks, the last column of TableÂ 2 compares the performance of the variants that we implemented with that of an ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT [7] program that directly encodes the problem statement of SubsectionÂ 11.1 using the ic library. For each problem, the first entry in this column lists the CPU time reported by ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT for an all-solution search, where we applied the same branching scheme as we used in OpenSolver. The other entries compare propagation strength, for which we ran the solvers without search, and compared the resulting domains of the variables. A mark â€˜=â€™ means that the computed domains are the same, â€˜+â€™ that our variant achieved stronger reduction, and â€˜-â€™ that constraint propagation is weaker than with ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT.

In addition, for cubes we verified that the number of nodes in the ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT search tree is identical to that for all variants except ğŸğ¦subscriptğŸğ¦\mathbf{f_{m}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğŸğ¬subscriptğŸğ¬\mathbf{f_{s}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which nicely fits with the comparable CPU times. In contrast, for the kyoto benchmark, the number of nodes in the search tree is substantially lower for our approaches than for ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT, and so is the CPU time. For the opt problem the CPU time for our approaches (except ğŸğ¦subscriptğŸğ¦\mathbf{f_{m}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) is also substantially lower than for ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT. We have not verified the number of nodes visited by the minimize/2 built-in, but the sequence of suboptimal solutions is identical to that found by our approaches (not verified for ğŸğ¦subscriptğŸğ¦\mathbf{f_{m}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). For this comparison we used ECLiğ‘–{}^{i}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPSeğ‘’{}^{e}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT version 5.10.

12 Conclusions

In this paper we discussed a number of approaches to constraint propagation for arithmetic constraints on integer intervals. To assess them we implemented them using the OpenSolver framework of [23], and compared their performance on a number of benchmark problems. We can conclude that:

  • â€¢

    Implementation of exponentiation by multiplication gives weak reduction. In the full decomposition approach x=ynğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›x=y^{n}italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should be used as an atomic constraint.

  • â€¢

    The optimization of the direct approach, where common powers of variables are divided out, can significantly reduce the size of the search tree, but the resulting reduction steps rely heavily on the division and addition of rational numbers. These operations are more expensive than their integer counterparts, because they involve the computation of greatest common divisors. As a result, our implementation of this approach was inefficient.

  • â€¢

    Introducing auxiliary variables can be beneficial in two ways: it may strengthen constraint propagation, as discussed in SectionsÂ 6 andÂ 7, and it may prevent the evaluation of subexpressions the variable domains of which did not change.

  • â€¢

    As a result, given an appropriate scheduling of the rules, the full and partial decomposition approaches perform better than the direct approach without the optimization, in terms of numbers of interval operations. Actual performance depends on many implementation aspects. However for our test problems the performance of variants ğ©ğ®subscriptğ©ğ®\mathbf{p_{u}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ©ğ¨subscriptğ©ğ¨\mathbf{p_{o}}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğŸğsubscriptğŸğ\mathbf{f_{e}}bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not differ much, except for one case where the decomposition of a single multiplication of all variables significantly reduced the size of the search tree.

Because of the inherent simplicity of the reduction rules and the potential reduction of the search tree, full decomposition of arithmetic constraints into multiplication, exponentiation, and linear constraints is our method of choice. However, a hierarchical scheduling of the resulting reduction rules is essential for efficient constraint propagation, and if a solver does not provide facilities for controlling the propagation order, the direct approach is preferable.

Given that the optimization of the direct approach can achieve a significant reduction of the search tree, it would be interesting to combine it with full decomposition. Depending on the effect of the symbolic manipulation, a selection of the optimized rules that enforce a particular constraint according to variant ğğ¨subscriptğğ¨\mathbf{d_{o}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT could be used as redundant rules. In this case, the internal computations need not be precise, and we could maintain the rational bounds as floating-point numbers, thus avoiding the expensive computation of greatest common divisors.

Acknowledgements

We would like to thank Maarten van Emden and the referees of earlier versions for useful comments.

Appendix

We provide here the proofs of the Bounds consistency Theorems 9.2 and 9.3, and the MULTIPLICATION Theorem 10.1.
